sections.abstract:
Background: Sarcopenia, the age -related decline in skeletal muscle mass and 
function, and obesity, commonly co -occur in older adults, a condition known as 
‘sarcopenic obesity’. It is currently unclear if socioeconomic status and physical activity 
are associated with sarcopenic obesity, whether sarcopenic obesity increases the risk 
of falls, poor bone health and fractures, and how sex and ethnicity influence 
associations of sarcopenic obesity with bone health.
sections.methods:
Four observational studies and one systematic review and meta -analysis 
were included in this thesis. The Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort (TASOAC) study, a 
prospective study of 1,099 Caucasian older adults aged ≥50 years , investigated 
whether socioeconomic status was associated with sarcopenic obesity and whether 
this association was mediated by physical activity . This study also determined risk 
factors associated with incident fractures among older adults with obesity defined by 
both BMI and body fat percentage. In a systematic review and meta-analysis including 
26 observational studies and randomised controlled trials, I explored whether older 
adults with sarcopenic obesity have poorer areal bone mineral density (aBMD), and 
greater risk of falls and fracture s compared to individuals with obesity alone, 
sarcopenia alone, and controls (without sarcopenia and obesity). In 1,057 individuals 
aged ≥50 years from the Indian Migration Study (IMS) and Andhra Pradesh Children 
and Parents Study (APCAPS), sex-specific differences in aBMD among Indians with 
sarcopenic obesity were investigated . Finally, cross -sectional analyses from three 
trials including a total of 74 Australian adults with obesity aged ≥55 years determined 
associations between components of obesity (body mass index (BMI) and body fat 
percentage) and sarcopenia (muscle mass: appendicular lean mass (ALM) and 
muscle strength/power) with bone variables assessed by high-resolution peripheral 

 4 
quantitative computed tomography (HR-pQCT) and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry 
(DXA). 
Results: In the TASOAC study, lower educational attainment and residing in 
disadvantaged areas were both associated with a higher likelihood for obesity, with 
the association for area of residence mediated by physical activity levels . However, 
only lower educational attainment was associated with a higher likelihood for 
sarcopenic obesity. We also observed in this population that obesity, defined by body 
fat percentage, as opposed to BMI, was associated with an increased likelihood for 
fractures in older adults, with falls risk assessment a consistent predictor for incident 
fractures in individuals with obesity . The systematic review and meta -analysis 
demonstrated that individuals with sarcopenic obesity had lower aBMD and higher 
falls risk compared with controls and obesity alone, while sarcopenic obesity was 
associated with higher aBMD but also higher non -vertebral fracture rates compared 
with individuals with sarcopenia alone. In Indian older adults, men with sarcopenic 
obesity had worse bone health, while both men and women with sarcopenia had 
poorer aBMD, compared with controls. In this population, obesity was associated with 
higher aBMD in women only. The cross-sectional study of Australian older adults with 
obesity demonstrated that higher BMI, ALM and muscle power were associated with 
more favourable bone microarchitecture, whereas body fat percentage was negatively 
associated with cortical area.
sections.conclusion:
This series of studies provides important insights into contributors to, 
and outcomes of, sarcopenic obesity among older adults. These findings suggest that 
disadvantaged socioeconomic st atus increases the risk of obesity and sarcopenic 
obesity, emphasising the need for public health messag ing targeting disadvantaged 
populations. In addition, older adults with sarcopenic obesity have lower aBMD and 

 5 
increased risk of falls compared to indiv iduals with obesity and those with neither 
condition. Despite having higher aBMD, older adults with sarcopenic obesity also have 
increased fracture risk compared to those with sarcopenia , which could be explained 
by poorer bone microarchitecture and the fact that higher b ody fat pe rcentage is 
associated with an increased risk of incident falls and fractures among older adults. 
Nonetheless, further research is required to determine sex - and ethnicity -specific 
associations of sarcopenic obesity with bone health and fracture risk. These findings 
also suggest the necessity of developing interventions targeting improvements in 
musculoskeletal health in this population of older adults.

Synopsis 
Ageing of populations and a concurrent rise in obesity around the world are 
leading to increased incidence of poor cardiometabolic and musculoskeletal health (1, 
2). Older adults with obesity have an increased risk for certain types of fractures, which 
may be partly explained by poorer bone microarchitecture and physical function (3, 4). 
However, there is inadequate attention to fracture prevention in this population 
because individuals with obesity generally have higher areal bone mineral density 
(aBMD) as estimated by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA), which is currently 
the gold standard assessment for osteoporosis (5). 
Obesity is primarily defined by body mass index ( BMI) which is positively 
associated with aBMD , and this likely contributes to the reported lower risk for 
osteoporosis in individuals with obesity (6, 7). In addition to estimating aBMD, DXA is 
a low cost and accurate measure of lean and fat mass, but it is unclear whether obesity 
defined by DXA-determined body fat percentage has differing associations with bone 
health and fracture s compared with BMI (8, 9) . Understanding these associations 
could improve identification of older adults with obesity who are susceptible to poor 
musculoskeletal health and improve provision of fracture prevention therapies in this 
population. 
Sarcopenia is another condition that is common among older adults and is 
defined as an age-associated loss of skeletal muscle mass and function (10-12). When 
occurring as a comorbid condition with obesity, ‘sarcopenic obesity’ may have severe 
consequences for musculoskeletal health-related outcomes and increase the risk of 
frailty and morbidity in older adults (10, 13) . A consensus definition for sarcopenic 
obesity has not yet been established, making it difficult for clinicians to diagnose this 
condition and to understand its risk factors, prevalence, and outcomes among older 

 23 
adults. Modifiable risk factors including physical activity, diet and socioeconomic 
status may predict the development of sarcopenic obesity but there is currently limited 
evidence on whether socioeconomic determinants including education, occupation 
and a rea of residence contribute to the prevalence of obesity, sarcopenia and 
sarcopenic obesity among older adults, and whether physical activity influences these 
associations. 
Limited data from primarily Caucasian populations indicates that older adults 
with sarcopenic obesity have poorer aBMD and up to three -fold higher rates of 
fractures compared with individuals with obesity alone and controls (without 
sarcopenia and obesity) (13-15). To date, data from prospective studies have not been 
synthesised, and studies in ethnic populations are currently unavailable 
Understanding the effects of sarcopenic obesity on bone health and fracture risk in 
diverse populations is important for developin g tailored interventions to prevent 
disability in older adults. 
This research program is comprised of two interlinked themes that 1) determine 
the associations between socioeconomic status and sarcopenic obesity and 2) explore 
the relationships between falls, fractures, bone health and sarcopenic obesity in older 
adults. These themes will be explored in five separate chapters which include cross -
sectional and prospective observational studies in addition to a systematic review and 
meta-analysis. 
The first theme investigates associations between socioeconomic factors and 
sarcopenic obesity in Australian community-dwelling older adults. The second theme 
consists of four chapters that separately (i) investigate risk factors associated with 
incident fractures am ong older individuals with and without obesity defined by both 
BMI and body fat percentage; (ii) compare falls risk and fracture rates, and aBMD, 

 24 
among older adults with sarcopenic obesity to those without; (iii) determine sex -
specific differences in bone health among an ethnic population of older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity and; (iv) explore associations of components of obesity and 
sarcopenia with bone microarchitecture in older adults with obesity. Overall, this thesis 
represents the first broad investigation of clinical and physiological relationships of 
sarcopenic obesity with musculoskeletal health among older adults. This research 
provides insights which can be translated into community-based programs and public 
health recommendations for older adults who are at risk of disability due to sarcopenic 
obesity.

Chapter 1.0 – Literature Review 
1.1 – Population ageing 
Worldwide p opulations of older adults are growing due to increased longevity and 
progress in medical sectors (16, 17) . Advances in, and greater accessibility to, 
healthcare services in the past two decades has promoted early diagnosis and timely 
treatments for health conditions therefore reducing the risk of mortality and increasing 
life expectancy (16, 18). Currently, there is no universally agreed definition for the 
terms ‘older adults’ although, the World Health Organisation classifies individuals aged 
60 years and above as older adults, this is not adaptable across certain countries (19, 
20). As such , for the purpose of this thesis, older adults will be used to describe 
individuals aged 50 years and above. 
By 2050, t he worldwide population of individuals aged 60 years and over is 
expected to double to 2.1 billion (21). This may pose a significant burden to the 
economic and healthcare sectors as ageing is associated with a progressive 
degeneration of vital tissues and organs, which contributes to the development of 
multiple chronic age-associated conditions (17, 21 -23). Chronic conditions with 
significant personal, economic, and societal burden are more prevalent in older adults 
and include obesity, certain types of cancer s, neurodegeneration, diabetes, 
osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, and several cardiovascular conditions (17, 24-27). As part 
of the normal ageing process, a cascade of underlying factors contributes to changes 
in many physiological and biological mechanisms increasing vulnerability to these 
conditions (22, 27-29). Specifically, changes in posture, balance, body composition, 
hormone levels, and inflammatory cytokines may increase the risk of frailty, morbidity, 
and institutionalisation among older adults (22, 28, 29) . These age-associated 
changes are determined and influenced by genetic and environmental factors (23, 30, 

 26 
31). A characteristic feature o f ageing is a decline in physical activity, as individuals 
become less active due to mobility restrictions (1, 32, 33). Declines in physical activity 
lead to a substantial reduction in overall energy expenditure , severely impactin g 
energy balance and increasing the risk of adiposity and developing obesity in older 
adults (1, 32, 33). 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 27 
1.2 – Obesity in the ageing population 
The term ‘obesity’ was officially recognised as a disease by the World Health 
Organisation (WHO) in 1948 (34, 35). The prevalence of obesity continues to increase 
worldwide and is recognised as a global public health problem (36-39). Since 1975, 
obesity prevalence has approximately tripled and is forecasted to increase further over 
the next two decades (40-43). By 2025, approximately 17 million Australians aged 20 
years and older are projected to be overweight or have obesity (44). This will have 
severe economic ramifications in the coming years , with obesity-related costs 
estimated to rise to $21 billion by 2025 (45, 46). Obesity in older adults is associated 
with severe health consequences including the development of diabetes, 
cardiovascular conditions, and certain cancer types all of which increase the risk of 
institutionalisation, multimorbidity, and mortality (1, 3, 47 ). Recent evidence has 
demonstrated that obesity increases the risk of premature death by 1.45 to 2.76-fold 
and reduces life expectancy by up to 20 years (47, 48). 
Nonetheless, obesity is common in older age; in 2017 -18, 46% of individuals 
aged 18 to 24 years were overweight or had obesity, compared with 78% of individuals 
aged 65 to 74 years (42). Ageing and obesity are closely related and share similar 
phenotypes (47). Age -related changes in body composition, reduced genomic 
integrity, mitochondrial d ysfunction, compromised immunity and increased systemic 
inflammation increase the risk of developing obesity (47). Changes in body 
composition due to age leads to an increase in overall body fat, redistribution of fat 
from peripheral to subcutaneous regions , and increase in abdominal adipose tissue, 
all of which have consequences on overall health outcomes (49-51). Indeed, obesity 
in older adults is associated with increased risk of disability and poorer quality of life 
(52). 

 28 
The WHO c ategorises body size using the body mass index ( BMI) 
classifications of underweight (BMI<18.5kg/m2), normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9kg/m2), 
overweight (BMI 25.0 -29.9kg/m2) and obesity ( BMI≥30kg/m2) (53). Although the se 
classifications have been well established world -wide due to low cost and feasibility, 
whether BMI is an accurate indicator of ob esity is currently debated (8, 9, 54, 55) . 
Body mass index is not reflective of adiposity as it is calculated using a height ( m2) 
and weight (kg) formula without accounting for body composition and may, therefore, 
underestimate the prevalence of obesity (8, 9, 54-56). Individuals with the same BMI 
may have different proportions of lean and fat mass (57). It is possible that the use of 
BMI to define obesity misclassifies those with excess body fat as being normal or 
overweight when in fact these individuals may be at increased risk of poor health 
outcomes (6, 8, 9). Likewise, those with normal fat mass with high lean mass may also 
be incorrectly classified as having obesity, which may prompt unnecessary treatment 
(6). Several studies have demonstrated that the use of BMI alone is therefore 
inadequate for the proper diagnosis of those individuals at risk of high adiposity and 
adverse clinical outcomes (58-61). Some studies consider w aist circumference to 
better explain obesity-related health risks, morbidity and death compared to BMI (60-
62). M easurement of waist circumference has been recommended , but it is less 
commonly used in clinical practice than BMI (60-62). Waist circumference may be a 
more accurate measure of fat distribution compared with BMI but may be more 
appropriate in identifying individuals with central obesity rather than general obesity 
(61-63). Abdominal obesity is defined as having a waist circumference of ≥88cm and 
≥102cm for women and men, respectively (61, 63). Recently, body fat percentage 
assessed by dual -energy X -ray absorptiometry (DXA) has been utilised to define 
obesity as it is one of the most precise and rel atively low -cost measures of body 

 29 
composition and provides a direct estimate of relative adiposity (6, 64, 65). There is 
no consensus for defining obesity by body fat percentage but recent evidence has 
proposed that body fat percentages of >25% for men and >35% for women correspond 
to a BMI of 30kg/m2 (WHO classification of obesity) in Caucasians (6, 9, 66-69). There 
is a scarcity of evidence regarding cut -points for body fat percentage in ethnic 
populations. Certain ethnic populations have a higher body fat percentage compared 
to Caucasians of the same age and BMI (70). It is important for future studies to 
determine optimal cut-points to understand the prevalence of obesity based on body 
fat percentage in ethnic populations of older adults. 
Studies have demonstrated that the use of body fat percentage may better 
assess and predict obesity and related outcomes such as ca rdiovascular conditions 
and diabetes than BMI or waist circumference (47, 54, 69, 71). However, it is important 
to note that the use of different definitions and cut-points have different effects on 
obesity prevalence and outcomes (47, 54, 69, 71) . In a study of 30,092 individuals 
aged 45 to 85 years from the Canadian Longitudinal Study, prevalence varied based 
on the definition of obesity used (71). This study demonstrated that the prevalence of 
obesity was lowest when defined by BMI (29%), followed by waist circumference 
(42%) with the highest prevalence by body fat percentage (73%) using cut-points of 
>25% for men and >35% for women (71). Similarly, a study of 451 individuals aged 
18 to 55 years reported that waist circumference and BMI underestimate the 
prevalence of obesity compared to body fat percentage (72). Recent e vidence 
indicates that instead of BMI to screen for obesity, the use of body fat percentage may 
provide more accurate estimates of obesity prevalence (6, 54, 73) . In addition , 
differences in environmental, lifestyle and genetic factors are likely to contribute to 
differences in body composition and body size , therefore generalised body fat 

 30 
percentage cut-points to define obesity cannot be utilised across diverse population s 
(58, 67, 74). It would therefore be beneficial to develop and utilise population-specific 
cut-points in order to understand the true burden of this disease in ethnic populations 
(58, 67, 74). However, in the absence of DXA in certain clinical settings, BMI or waist 
circumference may be utilised as a screening tool for obesity. With increasing 
prevalence across the globe, understanding the negative repercussions of obesity is 
crucial for early detection and treatment to reduce consequences associated with this 
condition in diverse populations of older adults, who have increased risk for disability 
due to obesity itself as well as other age-related conditions (75).

1.3 – Sarcopenia 
The term ‘sarcopenia’ was originally derived from the Greek ‘sarx’ (flesh) and 
‘penia’ (loss) to describe age -associated loss of skeletal muscle mass (11, 76, 77) . 
Overtime, the original definition of sarcopenia has evolved to incorporate age-related 
declines in both muscle mass and function (11, 76, 77). Some studies have argued 
that muscle strength, rather than muscle mass, is a more reliable indicator of functional 
impairment however, loss of bo th muscle mass and strength are important 
determinants of sarcopenia-related frailty (78). 
The progressive loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength has been attributed 
to age-related deterioration and alterations to a range of neurological, hormonal, and 
environmental pathways impairing physical activity, inflammation, nutrition, alpha -
motor units in the central nervous system and gene expression (78-81). Several of 
these age-associated changes contribute to decreases in motor neurons, muscle fiber 
size and number, contractility of fibers and an increase in fat infiltration causing 
impairment to muscle quality (78, 80, 81) . Muscle quality is a vital component of 
sarcopenia, which is a term used to describe muscle composition including 
intramuscular fat infiltration and muscle fibres (82-84). Due to technological limitations, 
it is difficult to assess muscle quality in clinical settings (82). In addition, muscle power 
is another important component of sarcopenia, which is defined as the product of the 
force and velocity of muscle contraction (85, 86). Muscle power is a component of 
physical function which can be assessed clinically via a stair climb power test . 
Emerging longitudinal studies have reported that muscle mass and strength 
decline as early as 30 years of age, with a more accelerated loss after the age of 60 
years (78, 87, 88) . The consequences of this loss of muscle mass and function are 
often severe in older adults and contribute to several adverse outcomes including 

 32 
increased disability, frailty and dependency (11). As such , sarcopenia is likely to 
impose a significant burden to the economy and healthcare sectors (89, 90). A meta-
analysis of five studies including a total of 2,832 individuals aged 70 years and above 
reported that older adults with sarcopenia were at an increased risk of hospitalisation 
(hazard ratio (HR): 1.57; 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.26, 1.94) compared to 
individuals without sarcopenia (89). In addition, costs associated with sarcopenia were 
as high as United States dollar (USD) $26.2 billion (approximately Australian dollar 
(AUD) $36.5 billion) in 2004 , which is likely to increase further with the emerging 
prevalence of sarcopenia among older adults (91). Despite its significant negative 
effects, sarcopenia remains underdiagnosed and mismanaged due to lack of a clear 
consensus definition (92). 
Muscle mass is often estimated from a whole -body DXA scan, by calculating 
appendicular lean mass (ALM), the sum of lean mass in the arms and legs (93). Most 
sarcopenia definitions utilise relative muscle m ass in the form of appendicular lean 
mass index (ALMI (kg/m2)), which is calculated as ALM (kg)/height (m 2) (93). Muscle 
strength is widely assessed using hand grip strength measured by a handheld 
dynamometer, which is regarded as the most reliable measure of muscle function and 
there is supporting evidence indicating that it is associated with relevant adverse 
health outcomes in older adults (82, 93, 94). Another commonly used assessment of 
muscle funct ion in some sarcopenia definitions is gait speed , which is generally 
measured on a 4m walking course (82, 93, 95) . Previous research has found gait 
speed to be associated with increased mortality and d isability in older adults and 
therefore also considered an important marker for sarcopenia (82, 93). 
Currently, there is no consensus definition for sarcopenia , with several 
definitions and different diagnostic criteria proposed (Table 1) (96). One of the most 

 33 
widely used sarcopenia definitions is the European Working Group on Sarcopenia in 
Older People (EWGSOP) definition, which was recently revised with new cut -points 
for low hand grip strength and ALMI (82). However, another recent definition from the 
Sarcopenia Definitions and Outcomes Consortium (SDOC) defines sarcopenia based 
on low hand grip strength, and low gait speed (95). In addition, t he revised Asian 
Working Group for Sarcopenia (AWGS) definition recommends measurement of low 
hand grip strength and ALMI for diagnosing sarcopenia in populations from Southeast 
Asian countries including China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Taiwan, 
and Thailand (97). Sarcopenia prevalence estimates vary widely as they are 
dependent upon several factors includ ing age, sex, ethnicity, and the definition used 
and it can range from anywhere between 5 to 50% (96, 98). The lack of a consensus 
definition and uniform diagnostic criteria is a barrier to sarcopenia assessment and 
management by clinicians and health professionals (92). Increasing knowledge and 
raising awareness among clinicians and health professional s may help prevent 
substantial loss of muscle mass and function and reduce the burden of sarcopenia 
(96).

1.4 – Sarcopenic obesity 
The comorbid presence of ‘sarcopenia’ and ‘obesity’ is known as ‘sarcopenic 
obesity’ (13, 78, 99-101). This term was first proposed in 2000 to describe sarcopenia 
accompanied by adipose tissue hypertrophy (102). O lder adults with sarcopenic 
obesity have higher risk of disability, hospitalisation and mortality compared to those 
with either sa rcopenia or obesity alone (13, 78, 99) . In individuals with sarcopeni c 
obesity there is a substantial increase in adipose tissue without a parallel increase in 
muscle mass and strength, potentially resulting in individuals having physical capacity, 
which is insufficient to support the required movement and function of their body (78). 
Sarcopenia and obesity synergistically increase the risk of negative health 
outcomes among older adults as they share similar pathophysiological factors 
including several lifestyle, hormonal and immunological mechanisms (79). Older 
adults with sarcopenic obesity undergo several changes in muscle composition 
including the infiltration of fat , which leads to a decrease in muscle quality and 
performance (92). Although, evidence has shown that individuals with sarcopenic 
obesity report lower levels of physical activity and energy expenditure predisposing 
them to increased risk of metabolic conditions and comorbidities, there is limited 
evidence on its associations with musculoskeletal health among older adults (93, 103). 
A study of 493 individuals (mean age of 53 years ) reported that sarcopenic obesity 
was associated with insulin resistance (homeostatic model assessment of insulin 
resistance (HOMA-IR) score), inflammation (measured as C-reactive protein levels ) 
and vitamin D deficiency (104). In another study consisting of 3,366 community -
dwelling older adults aged 65 years and older, sarcopenic obesity was associated with 
a 23% higher risk of cardiovascular diseases (105). In the British Regional Heart Study 
including 4,252 men (age 60 to 79 years), those with sarcopenic obesity had higher 

 36 
all-cause mortality risk (HR: 1.72; 95% CI: 1.35, 2.18) compared to individuals with 
sarcopenia alone ( HR: 1.21; 95% CI: 1.22, 1.63) and obesity alone ( HR: 1.21; 95% 
CI: 1.03, 1.42) (106). These findings collectively demonstrate the negative 
repercussions of sarcopenic obesity, particularly among older adults. 
Similar to sarcop enia, the prevalence of sarcopenic obesity is expected to 
increase globally due to the ageing population (79, 107, 108) . The prevalence of 
sarcopenic obesity ranges from 0 to 40% in older adults depending upon the 
population and diagnostic criteria applied (100, 109). Previously, studies have used 
several definitions of sarcopenic obesity, with combinations of obesity defined by BMI, 
waist circumference or body fat percentage and sarcopenia defined by muscle mass, 
muscle strength, or both (79, 100, 102). Several studies have previously utilised only 
a measure of muscle mass and fat mass to define sarcopenic obesity (110-114). The 
prevalence of sarcopenic obesity when defined by muscle mass and fat mass ranged 
from 4 to 12% and among those studies that defined sarcopenic obesity based on 
hand grip strength and BMI, the prevalence ranged between 4 to 9% (78). This raises 
concerns as there is compelling evidence from recent studies that sarcopenic obesity 
is determined by the deterioration of both muscle mass and function along with an 
increase in fat, which synergistically leads to a higher risk for metabolic diseases and 
functional limitations (82, 115). To understand the true prevalence of this condition , 
sarcopenic obesity should be defined by both muscle mass and function and fat mass 
unlike the abovementioned studies. 
The lack of a universal definition makes it difficult for clinicians to diagnose and 
treat this condition among older adults (100). However, a consensus statement for the 
diagnosis of sarcopenic obesity was recently proposed by the European Society for 
Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism (ESPEN) and the European Association for the 

 37 
Study of Obesity (EASO) (101). The joint consensus statement proposed that 
individuals suspected of having sarcopenic obesity should be evaluated on two levels, 
which includes screening and diagnosis, with diagnosis further staged into two levels 
beginning with the assessment of skeletal muscle functional parameters followed by 
an assessment of body composition assessed by DXA (101). This consensus 
statement includes several cut-points for adiposity, muscle mass and function based 
on ethnicity and gender making it difficult to achieve harmonisation of an operational 
definition (101). It is important to note that these criteria were based on expert opinion 
rather than being evidence-based (101). Studies are therefore required to validate 
these cut-points in diverse populations so that diagnosis of sarcopenic obesity can be 
standardised and easily examined by health professional s. Furthermore, having 
multiple screening, diagnosing, and staging levels for sarcopenic obes ity may be 
challenging in clinical settings (101). 
Importantly, although prevention and treatment strategies for sarcopenic 
obesity remain complex due to lack of universal definition, sarcopenic obesity is likely 
to be a modifiable condition (93, 116). Recent reviews have reported that prevention 
strategies for sarcopenic obesity include adequate consumption of nutrients including 
vitamin D, calcium and protein for muscle mass and strength, and exercise training to 
build muscle strength and reduce fat mass (93, 117). A study of 62 older women with 
a mean age of 68 years investigated the effects of a 12 -week resistance train ing 
program (1 or 3 sets per exercise) compared with controls (no exercise) on 
components of sarcopenic obesity and bone density (118). This study demonstrated 
that resistance training i mproved components of sarcopenic obesity , however a 
limitation is that this analysis was performed in physically independent women and 
may not be extrapolated to other populations or men (118). Further research is 

 38 
required to investigate dietary and exercise interventions that are most effective in 
improving body composition and physical function in older adults with sarcopenic 
obesity (119-121). This may be informed by studies which have identified risk factors 
for sarcopenic obesity. 

 39 
1.5 – Risk factors for sarcopenic obesity 
Decreases in muscle mass and function, and increased relative proportions of 
body fat, are largely inevitable during ageing, but their rate, and whether they progress 
to cause disablement, is dependent upon many factors (92, 93, 122) . The present 
growth in obesity and sarcopenic obesity prevalence is attributed to the 'obesogenic' 
modern environment (123-125). An environmental shift towards consumption of 
energy-dense and nutrient poor foods, due to increased availability, accessibility and 
affordability, promotes excess energy intake and weight gain increasing the risk of 
obesity (125). In addition, r isk factors including genetics, sex, age-related body 
composition changes, ethnicity, socioeconomic inequality, smoking, alcohol intake, 
food quality , hormone imbalance and physical activity may all be interrelated and 
together influence the risk of developing obesity, sarcopenia, and sarcopenic obesity 
in older adults (49, 126-130). There is a lack of evidence on how certain risk factors 
may increase the risk of obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity among older 
adults. This thesis specifically examines socioeconomic status, physical activity, sex 
and ethnicity as potential risk factors for obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity 
among older adults. Understanding the pathogenic and underlying mechanisms of 
how several risk factors contribute to gain in fat mass and/or loss of muscle mass and 
function may provide useful insights into the potential treatment and management of 
sarcopenic obesity among older adults. 
Age 
The prevalence of obesity has markedly increased among older adults (1, 3). 
Recent evidence has demonstrated that obesity rates exceeded 37.5% and 39.4% in 
men and women, respectively among individuals aged 60 years and more (3). 

 40 
Similarly, age-related biological changes drive sarcopenia which therefore makes age 
a major risk factor (11, 131). In a recent study including 369 individuals aged 18 years 
and older, the prevalence of sarcopenia (defined by FNIH and having self -reported 
functional limitation) and sarcopenic obesity (FNIH and having self-reported functional 
limitation with a BMI ≥30kg/m2) increased with age (132). The prevalence of 
sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity was 4.25% and 3.28%, respectively among 
individuals aged 18 to 39 years, 8.85% and 5.48%, respectively among individuals 
aged 40 to 64 years and 15.51% and 6.98%, respectively among individuals aged 65 
years and older (132). These findings suggest that age is a significant contributor to 
the development of sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity (79). 
 
Genetics 
Obesity is a highly heritable condition, with estimated heritability ranging from 
40 to 70%, and has been found to be influenced by several genetic traits (133, 134). 
Recent evidence has reported a ten -fold higher risk of developing obesity if both 
parents have this condition and a four-fold higher risk if one parent has obesity (135). 
Studies have identified several genes and over 500 genetic loci associated with 
adiposity traits that contribute to the onset of obesity, its severity and distribution of fat 
(49, 133, 136) . A recent meta -analysis including 339,224 individuals demonstrated 
that a range of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were associated with BMI and 
obesity (137). In addition, uncoupling proteins (UCP) which are proteins that are found 
in the inner mitochondrial membrane have also been found to be associated with 
increased risk of obesity (138). Allele variations of UCP, specifically, UCP1, UCP2 and 
UCP3 mutations decrease mitochondrial membrane potential, metabolic efficiency 
and energy expenditure consequently influencing body weight, BMI, and obesity (138). 

 41 
Limited genetic studies have also confirmed a strong relation ship between 
muscle mass and strength with hereditary , which may contribute to the development 
of sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity (139-141). It was estimated that the heritability 
of muscle strength could be anywhere between 30 to 80% and 50 to 80% for lea n 
mass (140). Recent studies have also found several genes linked to the development 
of sarcopenia and sarcope nic obesity , some of which include the genotypes of 
MTHFR, NRF2 and ACTN3 genes (140). These findings demonstrate that genetics 
plays a significant role in sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity in addition to age-related 
changes or lifestyle mechanisms , which may account for the development and 
progression of these conditions in older adults. 
 
Socioeconomic status 
Socioeconomic status is a major risk factor for unhealthy behaviours including 
physical inactivity, which consequently increases the risk of adverse health outcomes, 
morbidity, and mortality (142, 143). Education, social class, and income are the most 
commonly operationalised determina nts of socioeconomic status and are key 
predictors of overall health (142, 144). However, there is no consensus on the nominal 
definition of socioeconomic status and the same indicators cannot be used between 
developed and developing countries (145). For example , in developing countries, 
income is poorly reported and may therefore be an unreliable indicator of 
socioeconomic status whereas, income is an important determinant of socioeconomic 
status in developed countries (146). It is therefore important to develop more targeted 
and culturally acceptable determinants of socioeconomic status to better understand 
its implications across all countries. 

 42 
 Recent evidence has demonstrated that a higher level of education has been 
shown to improve health -related choices and health equity (142, 147) . Similarly, 
occupation/income contributes to better health outcomes and longer life expectancy 
(142, 147) . Some studies have also suggested that occupation may be another 
important determinant as occupation/ income allows for higher purchasing power for 
self-care and medical treatment contributing to better health outcomes and higher life 
expectancy (142, 148). In addition, residing in advantaged areas is beneficial to an 
individual’s health due to having better social support and access to health care 
services compared to those residing in disadvantaged areas who have limited access 
to facilities including hea lth services (149). Recent evidence has demonstrated that 
obesity is more prevalent among socioeconomically disadvantaged individuals 
represented by determinants such as low income, education, or occupation type (150-
152). In particular, in a study with 18,541 individuals aged 25 to 69 years, those with 
socioeconomic inequalities demonstrated a higher prevalence of obesity (152). Due 
to financial constraints and limited access to healthy food, socioeconomically 
disadvantaged individuals are more prone to consuming energy -dense, nutrient-poor 
diets, which is one of the key contributors to obesity (153). Additionally, indi viduals 
with socioeconomic inequalities are predisposed to unhealthy behaviours such as 
smoking, alcohol consumption and poor physical activity - all of which may further 
contribute to increased weight gain and ultimately obesity (154, 155). 
Several studies have demonstrated that economically stable older adults with 
better education and income have a lower prevalence of sarcopenia compared to 
those with socioeconomic disadvantages (147, 149, 156, 157) . A recent study 
consisting of 6,081 individuals with a mean age of 41.3 years reported that individuals 
with low household income (OR: 1.637; 95% CI: 1.159, 2.312) and low er education 

 43 
(OR: 2.351; 95% CI: 1.629, 3.394) had poorer hand grip strength compared to 
individuals with advantaged socioeconomic status (158). However, there are limited 
studies investigating the associations between socioeconomic determinants and 
sarcopenic obesity (147, 159-161). It has been established that socioeconomic status 
influences obesity and sarcopenia, however its effects on sarcopenic obesity are 
scarce among older adults. The relationship between socioeconomic status and 
sarcopenic obesity needs to be investigated to ensure the prevention of this condition 
and to maintain quality of life with ageing in this at -risk population. A study of 1,765 
individuals residing in Spain aged 65 years and older found no associations between 
socioeconomic status and sarcopenic obesity (147). In this study , individuals in the 
lower two quintiles of ALMI and body fat percentage were classified as having 
sarcopenic obesity (147). Conversely, in a study of 10,325 individuals from Louisiana, 
USA with mean age of 54 years, income and education were significantly associated 
with sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity (160). In this study, income was significantly 
associated with sarcopenic obesity, as men with an annual income of less than 
$20,000 were 2.78 times more likely to have sarcopenic obesity compared with those 
men with an annual income of $60,000 or more (160). Similarly, women with a high 
school and/or some college education were 2.68 times more likely to have sarcopenic 
obesity compared with women with at least a college degree (160). Sarcopenia in the 
abovementioned study was defined as one standard deviation below the gender -
specific means (cut-points for men: <7.8kg/m2; women: <5.88kg/m2) and obesity was 
defined by waist -to-hip ratio (cut -points for men: ≥90; women: ≥0.85) (160). 
Differences in demographics, physical activity levels, body composition and the 
definition of sarcopenic obesity used in the two studies mentioned above could have 
contributed to the differences in associations between socioeconomic status and 

 44 
sarcopenic obesity. In addition, lack of physical activity or inability to exercise due to 
socioeconomic inequalities is another contributor that may play a role in the 
development of sarcopenia, though research on its effects on sarcopenic obesity are 
limited (158). There is therefore a greater need for more studies on effects of 
socioeconomic inequalities on sarcopenic obesity and to investigate whether physical 
activity influences these associations. 
 
Smoking and alcohol consumption 
Smoking increases the risk of obesity as heavy smokers have high BMI (162). A 
study of 499,504 adults aged 31 to 69 years reported that among smokers, the risk of 
obesity increased with the number of cigarettes smoked (163). Some studies have 
also examined the associations between smoking and sarcopenia (164-166). In a 
study of 845 men aged 45 to 85 years, it was reported that smokers had lower relative 
appendicular skeletal muscle mass (167). However, there are limited studies on the 
effects of smoking on sarcopenic obesity. A cross-sectional study of 9,385 individuals 
aged 50 years and more reported that heavy smokers were more likely to have 
sarcopenic obesity (OR: 9.53; 95% CI: 1.65, 55.01) (164). Additionally, the biological 
mechanisms for t he effects of smoking on sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity are 
currently unclear. Nevertheless, a proposed mechanism for the effects of smoking on 
muscle is that the volatile components of cigarettes including aldehydes, reactive 
oxygen species and reactiv e nitrogen species, which enter via the blood stream into 
the skeletal muscle increasing oxidative stress leading to protein degradation 
accelerating the progression of sarcopenia among older adults (168). 

 45 
Excess alcohol intake also has adverse effects on health and has been 
attributed to increased body weight and obesity (169, 170). In 8,864 individuals aged 
17 years and older, obesity risk was 70% higher for heavy drinkers compared with 
light drinkers (169, 171). Evidence suggests that alcohol consumption increases food 
intake due to its effects on a number of hormones linked to satiety such as leptin (172). 
Aside from increased appetite, alcohol also influences energy storage as it inhibits fat 
oxidation with excess intake of alcohol regularly leading to fat sparing, increasing body 
fat over time (169). Although the effects of alcohol on weight gain and obesity have 
been studied extensively, whether alcohol consumption is a risk factor for sarcopenia 
and sarcopenic obesity remains poorly investigated. Excess ethanol may promote the 
inhibition of muscle protein synthesis and also simultaneously increase muscle 
autophagy (173, 174) . In the Dementia Research Grou p, a multicentre population -
based study of individuals aged 65 years and older, moderate alcohol drinking was 
significantly associated with sarcopenic obesity (OR: 1.76; 95% CI: 1.21, 2.57) but not 
sarcopenia (OR: 1.21; 95% CI: 0.91, 1.62) (173). In contrast, a meta -analysis of 13 
studies including 13,155 individuals has reported alcohol drinking is not a risk factor 
for sarcopenia (OR: 0.77; 95% CI: 0.67 -0.88) (175). There are, however, a few 
limitations in this meta -analysis as the relationship between drinking pattern and 
sarcopenia was not confirmed. In addition, none of the studies included in the meta -
analysis had a primary focus on the associations between alcohol consumption and 
sarcopenia (175). 
 
 
 

 46 
Sex 
 The prevalence of obesity among men and women differs; obesity generally is 
more prevalent in women compared with men (170, 176-179). In a study conducted 
among 3,799 individuals aged 30 to 70 years, a larger proportion of women ( 39.5%) 
had obesity compared with men (14.5%) when defined by BMI≥30kg/m 2 (180). Sex 
differences in mobilisation and distribution of adipose tissue storage, insulin sensitivity, 
lipoprotein profiles, gonadal hormones, and physical activity may explain differences 
in obesity prevalence (170, 176 -178). In p articular, the menopause transition in 
women leads to a shift in hormonal levels with a substantial loss of estrogen 
production, which is associat ed with an increase in fat mass, fat redistribution and 
eventually weight gain , contributing to adverse health outcomes (181, 182) . In 
addition, men are also more likely to be physically active and engage in higher levels 
of physical activity compared to women, which could also explain disparities in obesity 
prevalence (162, 170, 183, 184). 
Many studies have also demonstrated that the onset of functional decline and 
muscle mass loss differs among m en and women (12, 185, 186). Overall, men have 
a faster deterioration of muscle mass even though they have more initial muscle mass 
compared with women (185). Substantial decrease s in testosterone and insulin-like 
growth factor ( IGF)-1 levels are some of the main contributors to this observed 
increased risk of sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity among men compared to women 
(185). In contrast, a longitudinal study of 4,000 community-dwelling older adults aged 
>64 years stated that women had -2.02% loss of ALM but men had -1.59% loss of 
ALM after four years (187). There are contradictory findings regarding the prevalence 
of sarcopenia, with s ome studies reporting the prevalence to be higher among men 

 47 
compared to women while, others have stated the opposite (96, 185, 188-190). These 
disparities in prevalence may be explained by differences in sarcopenia definitions or 
due to ethnicity-related differences in genetics, lifestyles, body composition, physical 
activity and fat distribution (188). Understanding these disparities can benefit future 
trials to develop sex -specific interventions to reduce the risk of sarcopenic obesity 
among this population of older adults. 
In a cross-sectional study of 631 community-dwelling older adults aged over 65 
years in East China, the prevalence of sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity was higher 
in men (19.2% and 7.0% , respectively) compared to women (8.6% and 2.4%, 
respectively) (185). A strength of this study was that sarcopenia was defined based 
on the AWGS definition. However, a limitation was that participants with obesity were 
required to have a body fat percentage above the 60th percentile of the study sample 
of the same sex, which corresponded to 27.2% for men and 35.9% for women (185). 
The cut-points used in this study may not be comparable with other studies and the 
use of this definition could have influenced the prevalence of sarcopenic obesity in this 
population (185). In contrast, a cross-sectional study in 119,494 individuals aged 18 
to 90 years from the Dutch Lifelines cohort study reported that the prevalence of 
sarcopenic obesity was 0.9% in men and 1.4% in women (191). In this study, women 
had a higher prevalence of sarcopenic obesity com pared to men in all age groups 
(191). These findings are limited as the definition of obesity was based on the WHO 
BMI cut-points and sarcopenia was defined by 24-hour urine creatinine excretion to 
measure muscle mass (191). In addition to these contradictory findings, there are very 
limited studies evaluating sex-differences in the prevalence of sarcopenic obesity in 
certain ethnic populations of older adults. 
 

 48 
Ethnicity 
Many studies have demonstrated ethnic differences in health outcomes during 
the ageing process (192-195). Some ethnic groups are predisposed to poorer health 
outcomes during ageing compared with those of Caucasian descent, such as 
increased risk of chronic diseases, functional limitations, morbidity, and mortality (192, 
193, 196). In a study involving 236,289 older adults with a mean age of 74 years , it 
was demonstrated that individuals of diverse ethnic backgrounds were at a higher risk 
for adverse health outcomes such as obesity and chronic conditions compared with 
non-Hispanic Whites (196). There are several potential reasons contributing to this 
increased risk of poor overall health in certain ethnic groups, and include differences 
in: metabolism, body composition, genetics, environment, and lifestyle factors (192, 
197-199). Recent evidence demonstrates that certain ethnic populations may also be 
more susceptible to obesity (58, 200). A study of 47,970 individuals aged 18 years and 
older reported that being Hispanic (odds ratio (OR): 1.47; 95% confidence interval (CI): 
1.31, 1.65) and Black (OR: 2.04; 95% CI: 1.65, 2.53) were associated with higher odds 
of obesity compared with Whites. However, being Chinese (OR: 0.28; 95% CI: 0.18, 
0.45), Korean (0.14; 95% CI: 0.04, 0.46), and Vietnamese (OR: 0.28; 95% CI: 0.14, 
0.58) were all associated with lower odds of obesity compared with Whites (201). In 
this study however, obesity was defined by Asian BMI cut-points and the use of body 
fat percentage may affect obesity prevalence (201). On average, most Asian 
ethnicities have greater average body fat percentage compared with Whites of the 
same age and BMI (70). This was evident in a study with 115 Chinese and 114 White 
men aged 28 to 63 years, where Chinese men had more total body fat and central fat 
compared with White men (58). In a nother population-based study which included 
21,399 adults aged 20 years and older, Asian populations had changes in body 

 49 
composition over time as a significant increase in body fat percentage was observed 
among non-Hispanic Asians from 25.5% (2011 to 2012) to 28.2% (2017 to 2018), but 
remained stable among other ethnic groups (Hispanic, non-Hispanic White, non-
Hispanic Black) (202). Although this study investigated longitudinal changes in body 
fat percentage in different ethnic populations , the differences in obesity prevalence 
based on body fat percentage cut-points was not investigated (202). Therefore, further 
research is necessary to explore the differences in the prevalence of obesity defined 
by body fat percentage in various ethnic populations. 
Similarly, there are ethnic differences in sarcopenia components as previous 
research demonstrat ed disparities in muscle mass, strength, and function between 
different ethnic groups (197-199, 203). The rate of decline in muscle strength with age 
is much more rapid in Asian populations compared with Caucasians and other ethnic 
groups, along with a greater deterioration in muscle function (187, 199). A recent study 
including 10,325 individuals with a mean age of 54 years reported that sarcopenia 
prevalence was highest in Asian men (40.6%) and women (30.1%) (160). In this 
study, the prevalence of sarcopenic obesity was also highest in Asian m en (14.4%) 
and women (8.0%) whereas, it was the lowest among Black men (3.7%) and women 
(0.9%) (160). Sarcopenia was defined based on one standard deviation below the 
gender-specific means of height-adjusted appendicular skeletal muscle mass with cut-
points of <7.8kg/m2 for men and <5.88kg/m 2 for women (160). Although this study 
investigated sarcopenic obesity in populations including African -American/Black, 
Asians, Caucasian/White, and Hispanic/Latino, studies in specific ethnic populations 
of low to middle income countries such as India are currently scarce (160). The Asian 
continent consists of 48 countries and each of these sub -populations have different 
lifestyles and environmental f actors including culture, food consumption, body 

 50 
composition, physical activity, and socioeconomic status - all of which may contribute 
to differences in sarcopenic obesity prevalence (204-206). As such, demographic 
groups should be individually assessed to determine the prevalence and effects of 
sarcopenic obesity in various populations unlike the abovementioned study , which 
grouped all Asian countries together (160). 
 
Diet 
Diet behaviours play a major role in the development of obesity, sarcopenia 
and sarcopenic obesity and are likely to be key in their management (93, 98, 141) . 
Weight gain is often caused by an imbalance in energy intake and expenditure due to 
increased sedentary behaviours and poor dietary consumption including excessive 
intake of energy-dense and high fat diets (182, 207, 208). Increased availability and 
accessibility of fast foods stimulates excessive intake of high -calorie, low -nutrient 
foods, increasing the risk of obesity and sarcopenic obesity (208). 
Vitamin D, or more specifically its metabolite 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D), 
has been identified as an important nutrient contributing to adverse musculoskeletal 
outcomes and also the development of obesit y, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity 
(98, 209). Vitamin D deficiency, defined as 25(OH)D blood concentrations of less than 
50nmol/L can be treated through vitamin D supplements but can also be obtained 
through exposure to sunlight and diet (210, 211). Insufficient vitamin D levels modulate 
inflammatory response s, affect adipogenesis and accumulating evidence indicates 
that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk of obesity (212-214). 
Likewise, severe vitamin D deficiency has also been found to cause muscle weakness 
and pain particularly in the lower limbs among older adults (210). Skeletal muscle is 

 51 
severely affected by low vitamin D levels due to its contribution to the function of fast-
twitch type II muscle fibres (210, 211). Muscle contractions and power are controlled 
by type II muscle fibers, and vitamin D deficiency is linked to muscle fibre atrophy 
consequently compromising muscle health and function (210, 215, 216) . Therefore, 
adequate concentrations of v itamin D may be important for physical performance , 
muscle health and reducing risk of adverse musculoskeletal outcomes (210). 
In addition , p rotein is another important nutrient that is associated with 
sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity , as proteins stimulate the synthesis of muscle 
proteins (209, 217). Several studies have identified that adequate protein intake is 
consistently associated with better muscle health among older adults (209, 218-221). 
The recommended dietary protein intake for all adults over the age of 18 years 
includes 0.8 g/kg/day, however this recommendation is currently under debate (218). 
According to some studies, to counteract age-associated losses of muscle mass, older 
adults may require a higher protein intake with approximately 1 -1.25g/kg/day (222-
224). It has been estimated that a large proportion of adults (38% of men and 41% of 
women) have dietary intakes below the recommended daily allowance making them 
susceptible to increased risk of sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity (218, 220). A study 
consisting of 18 women aged 41 to 74 years found that individuals with sarcopenic 
obesity showed improvements in body composition and muscle strength ( improved 
hand grip strength by 1.6kg) after consuming a high-protein diet for four months (1.2-
1.4g/kg/day) (225). However, these findings are limited as the sample size was small 
(225). Further research is needed to determine the most effective dietary protein intake 
to prevent sarcopenic obesity in older adults. 
 
 

 52 
Physical activity 
Physical activity and exercise are recommended as one of the most effective 
means to prevent and manage several diseases including obesity, sarcopenia and 
sarcopenic obesity, particularly among older adults (226-231). Physical inactivity and 
increased sedentary behaviours have emerged as major risk factor s for higher levels 
of disability and all -cause mortality among older adults (232). Modern-day lifestyles 
are characterised by sedentary behaviour, which is the main contributor to increased 
risk of obesity (233). Alarmingly, one in four adults in USA spend approximately 70% 
of their waking hours sitting (233). This shift in increased sedentary behaviour results 
from increased television viewing, working from home and commuting to work by car, 
thereby decreasing overall locomotion and energy expenditure (233). In a cross -
sectional study of 162 community -dwelling older adults aged 60 years and older, an 
increment of one hour in overall sitting time was associated with a greater risk for 
sarcopenia (226). There are multiple mechanisms by which p rolonged sedentary 
behaviours and reduced energy expenditure increase the risk of sarcopenia and 
sarcopenic obesity (234, 235). Sedentary behaviour results in fewer skeletal muscle 
contractions, which decreases lipoprotein lipase activity and triglyceride clearance and 
also result s in poor glucose -stimulated insulin secretion (233). In addition, l ack of 
muscle contractions causes an infiltration of fat, which is associated with poor muscle 
mass, power, quality, function, and strength therefore increasing the risk of sarcopenic 
obesity (80, 226, 236) . In a study of 871 older adults aged 65 years and older 
proinflammatory cytokines were associated with the development of sarcopenic 
obesity causing mobility limitations (78, 237) . P rolonged periods of sedentary 
behaviour leads to changes in hormonal levels (including testosterone, IGF -1, 
myostatin and tumour necrosis factor -alpha ( TNF-α) and neural activity (including 

 53 
motor unit denervation), which also contributes to developing sarcopenic obesity (226, 
238). 
Muscle impairment due to age -associated mobility limitation s may lead to 
fluctuations in metabolic rate , which may also aggravate sedentary behaviour , 
resulting in weight gain and subsequent sarcopenic obesity (78). Therefore, the effects 
of physical activity on sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity may be cyclic as these 
conditions also contribute to further reductions in physical activity (239). 
Studies have demonstrated that physical activity may reduce the risk of 
developing sarcopenic obesity among older adults (240, 241) . In a study including 
3,367 older adults aged 65 years and older, higher levels of physical activity were 
associated with a 55% and 29% lower risk of developing sarcopenic obesity in men 
and women, respectively (240, 241). Physical activity should be encouraged among 
older adults to prevent the risk of developing sarcopenic obesity and its negative 
repercussions.

 54 
1.6 – Bone and muscle health 
1.6.1 Osteoporosis 
Osteoporosis is a global public health problem among older adults and is 
characterised by severe loss of bone mass and bone microarchitectural deterioration 
(242, 243) . Osteoporosis is defined using areal bone mineral density (aBMD) 
assessed by DXA , which generates an output of T-score (a measure of standard 
deviation, which calculates bone density compared with what is usually expected in a 
healthy young adult) (244). Osteopenia is often a precursor to osteoporosis and is a 
milder form of bone loss , which is defined as having a T -score between -1 and -2.5, 
while osteoporosis is defined as having a T-score of ≤-2.5 at the total hip and lumbar 
spine (245-247). 
Approximately 10 million Americans aged 50 years and older had osteoporosis 
in 2020, and with the increased ageing of populations, the prevalence of osteoporosis 
is expected to rise further (248). In a recent systematic review and meta -analysis of 
older adults, including 40 studie s from around the world, with a total sample size of 
79,127 individuals , the highest prevalence of osteoporosis was reported in Asia 
(24.3%), followed by Europe (16.7%) and was the lowest in USA (11.5%) (249). 
Therefore, it is clear that the prevalence of osteoporosis differs according to ethnicity 
(250-252). 
Age-related loss of bone mass increases the risk of fractures, morbidity, and 
hospitalisation (29, 51, 253, 254) . The annual cost of osteopenia, osteoporosis , and 
related fractures in Austral ians was AUD $4.3 billion in 2020 (255). Costs related to 
treatment for falls, fracture s and poor bone health is expected to substantially rise 
within the coming years (255). 

 55 
Obesity has a complex relationship with bone health (4). Individuals with 
obesity are less likely to be screened for osteoporosis or receive bone protective 
medications (256, 257). In the Global Longitudinal study of Osteoporosis in Women 
(GLOW) study including 60,393 individuals aged 55 years and older, among women 
with obesity, only 27% of those with incident fractures were receiving bone protective 
medications as opposed to 41% and 57% among those with normal weight and 
underweight, respectively (257). Although, t his is likely due to evidence that body 
weight is positively associated with higher aBMD , DXA tends to overestimate bone 
health in these individuals (258-261). A study consisting of 3,296 individuals aged 50 
years and older reported an increase in 0.0082g/cm2 in aBMD for every unit increase 
in BMI (7). Likewise, in another study including 358 men aged between 50 and 89 
years, there was a positive relationship between aBMD at all sites (including lumbar 
spine, femoral neck, and total hip) and BMI (all p<0.05) (262). As such, high BMI is 
considered to have a protective effect on bone mass potentially resulting in bone 
health in this population being neglected by health professionals (257, 263, 264). 
BMI is not nece ssarily representative of adiposity, and that fat mass per se is 
not beneficial for bone health (8, 263) . Recent evidence suggests other indices of 
obesity, such as DXA-determined body fat percentage, may be negatively associated 
with aBMD and detrimental to bone health (7, 8, 265, 266) . This was confirmed in a 
study of 1,992 adults with a mean age of 48.7 years , which reported a negative 
correlation between aBMD and body fat percentage in Korean men and women (265). 
Further, a study in 173 individuals with obesity aged 65 years and more showed that 
higher adiposity (DXA -determined fat mass) was associated with lower aBMD and 
higher adipokine levels increasing frailty (267). Likewise, a study in 6,776 individuals 
aged 20 years and older showed that higher body fat percentage was associated with 

 56 
reduced aBMD , particularly among men (268). Excess body fat contributes to an 
increase in pro -inflammatory cytokines including interleukin (Il) -1β, Il -6 and TNF -α 
promoting osteoclast activity, bone resorption therefore decreasing bone mass and 
impairing overall bone health (4, 266). Individuals with higher fat mass have also been 
reported to have higher levels of serum parathyroid hormone ( main regulator of 
calcium homeostasis) , which causes bone resorption and has negative effects on 
aBMD (4, 269). Further research is required to determine the associations of obesity, 
assessed by direct measures of body fat, with bone health in older adults. 
Bone and muscle interact with each other mechanically and metabolically 
(242). Recent evidence suggests that t here may be a potential interconnection 
between osteoporosis, sarcopenia, and obesity as there are shared risk factors for the 
development of these conditions (Figure 1) (270-272). The co-morbid presence of 
these conditions is common among older adults due to age-related changes in several 
mechanisms including changes to body composition and hormonal levels , which 
promote the simultaneous loss of bone and muscle mass along with an increase in fat 
mass (270-272). However, a higher proportion of women are expected to have the 
combined presence of sarcopenic obesity and osteoporosis due to ovarian hormone 
deficiency as part of ageing , which leads to substantial negative implications on 
musculoskeletal outcomes (270). As previously stated, estrogen deficiency plays a 
both direct and indirect role in increasing fat mass and promotes the simultaneous loss 
of both bone and muscle mass among older women (270). 
Studies have demonstrated that sarcopenic obesity increases the risk of 
osteoporosis among older adults (114, 273, 274). In a cross-sectional study of 7,449 
Korean individuals aged 50 years and more , those with sarcopenic obesity had an 

 57 
eight-fold higher likelihood for osteoporosis compared with those without sarcopenia 
or obesity (13, 114). Similarly, in a study including 183 New Zealanders with a mean 
age of 73 years showed that the prevalence of osteoporosis was approximately two-
fold greater in individuals with sarcopenic obesity compared to individuals with obesity 
alone (273, 275). Likewise, in a study of 1,089 individuals residing in Australia with a 
mean age of 62 years, individuals with sarcopenic obesity (low muscle mass with high 
fat mass) and dynapenic obesity (low muscle strength with high fat mass) had a higher 
prevalence for osteoporosis/osteopenia compared with those with obesity alone (275). 
Even though each of the abovementioned studies evaluated the associations between 
sarcopenic obesity and bone health in various populations, there is still a paucity of 
research on whether sarcopenic obesity increases the risk of osteoporosis in specific 
ethnic commu nities. Therefore, m ore research is required to understand the 
differences in sarcopenic obesity among different ethnic groups , as genetic and 
environmental variables related to poor aBMD and osteoporosis may put specific 
populations at a higher risk of adverse health outcomes. 
Several technical advances in novel imaging modalities have increased the 
accuracy of diagnosing musculoskeletal-related conditions among older adults (276). 
DXA is a two -dimensional measure of aBMD and is the current gold standard for 
diagnosing osteoporosis among older adults (5, 277). Osteoporosis is associated with 
compromised bone strength and microarchitecture – both of which DXA cannot 
account for, as it cannot distinguish between cortical and trabecular bone (244, 278). 
In addition, aBMD may cause a scaling artifact, which inaccurately estimates smaller 
bones as having lower aBMD and may therefore misclassify individuals with short 
stature as having osteoporosis (279). Bone mineral apparent density (BMAD) 
calculated as aBMD/√bone area accounts for short stature, which should be used to 

 58 
avoid overdiagnosis of osteoporosis (280). Utilising BMAD may help account for the 
size of bones to reduce the risk of ethnic-specific discrepancies as the average height 
among Asians is much lower compared with Caucasian populations, which may 
influence the differences in aBMD and osteoporosis prevalence (279-282). In the Early 
Postmenopausal Interventional Cohort study including 1,367 Caucasian and 162 
Asian women aged between 45 to 59 years, aBMD in Asian women was 4.6% lower 
than in Caucasian women without any differences in aBMD once adjusted for height 
(283, 284). As a result, this study emphasises the importance of accounting for body 
size when evaluating the ethnic differences in aBMD (284). 
 Although, DXA is a commonly used imaging modality to measure aBMD, it has 
been found to be less accurate among individuals with obesity due to excess soft 
tissue (256). Specifically, layering of fat at the lumbar spine site leads to inaccuracies 
in aBMD measurement. In contrast to DXA, high -resolution peripheral quantitative 
computed tomography (HR -pQCT) is a novel three -dimensional assessment of the 
bone microarchitecture and volumetric BMD (vBMD) , which distinguishes between 
cortical and trabecular bone parameters (285, 286) . HR -pQCT would therefore be 
utilised to assess bone health among older adults as it provides data on bone quality, 
geometry and strength , which will contribute to improving fracture risk in individuals 
with sarcopenic obesity . However, there are certain challenges and limitations with 
HR-pQCT (287). Firstly, scans can only be performed at two peripheral skeletal sites 
(radius and tibia) (287). Also, HR -pQCT is highly sensitive to motion artifacts and 
therefore cannot be performed on extremely frail and fragile individuals (287). In 
addition, HR-pQCT cannot be used as a screening tool for poor bone health, as its 
currently prohibitive costs prevent them from being widely available in clinical settings 
(287).

1.6.2 Falls and fractures 
Falls are a leading contributor to hospitalisation and injury death among 
Australian older adults , with 43% of hospitalised injuries and 39% of injury deaths 
reported due to falls in 2018 -19 (288, 289). Previous literature has demonstrated a 
number of risk factors including age, fear of falling, multimorbidity, psychological stress 
and physical weakness, which may predispose older adults to a greater risk of falls 
(255, 290). Falls are associated with several detrimental effects on older adults as 
they lead to increased risk of physical disability, functional impairment, dependency in 
daily activities and institutionalisation (290). Falls are one of the main causes of 
fractures among older adults, increasing morbidity and mortality, which places a 
substantial economic healthcare burden (257). One in three women aged 50 years 
and over will sustain a fracture during their lifetime, which accumulates to an estimated 
annual cost of USD $17 billion (approximately AUD $23 billion) in USA (257). 
Some studies have reported that o lder adults with obesity have an increased 
risk of fall s (291, 292). In the Osteoporotic Fractures in Men study , including 5,834 
individuals aged 65 years and above , the falls rate was lowest in the youngest and 
normal weight men but highest among the oldest men with the highest BMI (292). 
Another study of 226 women aged between 60 to 80 years reported that individuals 
with obesity had a greater probability of falls compared to normal weight women (293). 
This overall higher r isk of falls among individuals with obesity may be due to the 
distribution of fat impacting balance and postural sway (294). This was confirmed in a 
study consisting of 280,035 adults aged 45 to 79 years, as the risk of falling in the 
previous 12 months was higher among those with obesity compared to those without 
obesity (295). Individuals with obesity have a greater fear of falling, which may lead to 

 61 
a reduction in physical activity and subsequent functional impairment , together 
contributing to the increased falls risk (294). 
Fractures are also common among older adults with obesity despite a 
perception that individuals with obesity are protected against fractures due to high 
aBMD and increased soft -tissue padding (257, 296) . Recent findings have 
demonstrated that older adults with obesity (defined by BMI) have an increased risk 
of fractures, particularly at peripheral sites (297). In the aforementioned GLOW study, 
a prospective study of 60,393 women aged 50 years and older, fractures in women 
with obesity accounted for 23% of previous fractures and 22% of incident fractures 
(257, 264). This study also found that the risk of fractures at the ankle and upper leg 
was significantly higher among those with obesity compared to those women without 
obesity (257, 264). This increased risk of site -specific fractures among older adults 
with obesity may partly be explained by poorer bone microarchitecture and higher falls 
risk (285, 297-299). However, there is a scarcity of research investigating the effects 
of obesity on bone microarchitecture among older adults. Conversely, n umerous 
studies have reported obesity to be protective against hip fractures (256, 300-303). 
However, in the Million Women Study, a prospective study of 925,345 women (mean 
age of 57 years) in the United Kingdom, almost half of all postmenopausal hip fractures 
occurred in women who were overweight or had obesity (300). This discrepancy could 
be due to the fact th at obesity was defined by body fat percentage in the Million 
Women Study but by BMI in studies that found a protective effe ct for hip fractures 
(256, 300-303). As previously stated, evidence demonstrates that unlike BMI, body fat 
percentage is negatively associated with bone health, therefore challenging the use of 
BMI to define obesity (Figure 2) (265, 304). There is a lack of evidence to support the 

 62 
fact that different obesity definitions have varied effects on musculoskeletal health 
outcomes such as fractures and bone microarchitecture requiring further investigation. 
Sarcopenia may further exacerbate the risk of falls and fractures among those 
with obesity (13). The dual effects of weakness from sarcopenia and the need to carry 
excess weight from obesity lead to increased risk of poor physical function and 
mobility, which may predispose these individuals to a greater risk of falls and fractures 
(14, 15, 305 -307). Although, multiple studies have investigated the associations 
between ageing and falls and fractures, there is limited evidence on whether olde r 
adults with sarcopenic obesity represent a subset of the population who are at an 
increased risk of these adverse outcomes. 
Studies in primarily Caucasian populations have demonstrated that individuals 
with sarcopenic obesity had poorer aBMD and a three-fold increased risk of falls and 
fractures compared to those with obesity alone and controls (without sarcopenia and 
obesity) (14, 15, 306). In addition, in a prospective cohort study of 11,020 multiethnic 
cohort women, sarcopenic obesity was associated with a greater risk of falls compared 
with controls (307). In another study with 598 individuals aged 65 to 98 years from the 
Geelong Osteoporosis Study, falls were more common among those with sarcopenic 
obesity (40.6%) compared to those without (26.8%). The combination of sarcopenia 
and obesity increases the risk of fractures in older adults as both sarcopenia and 
obesity increase falls risk (13). In a study of 1,089 individuals with a mean age of 62 
years, it was evident that women with sarcopenic obesity had higher fracture rates 
compared with individuals with obesity alone (incidence rate ratios: 2.82; 95% CI: 1.42, 
5.60) (275). Reduction in muscle mass and weakness in muscle strength from 
sarcopenia and the effects of additional weight on bones due to obesity, negatively 
contributes to body stability increasing the risk of frailty and fractures (308). Several 

 63 
mechanisms including elevated proinfla mmatory factors, hormonal imbalance , poor 
physical function, and poor bone microarchitecture may increase the risk of falls and 
fractures among individuals with sarcopenic obesity (123, 307). However, there is a 
scarcity of research on the factors that contribute to this increased falls and fracture 
risk in this group of older adults . In the absence of specific therapies for the 
management of sarcopenic obesity, further research is required to understand these 
factors, which will aid in the development of effective interventions to prevent falls and 
fractures in this high-risk population (309, 310).

1.7 Conclusion 
 
 Older adults have increased risk for functional limitations, disability and 
morbidity due to age-related progression of sarcopenia , and the presence of obesity 
may significantly exacerbate these negative health outcomes . Several factors 
including age, sex, genetics, enviro nmental and lifestyle factors may influence the 
development, progression and severity of sarcopenic obesity. Despite the fact that 
evidence suggests that sarcopenic obesity leads to adverse health outcomes, 
research on its effects on aBMD, bone microarchitecture, falls and fractures in diverse 
populations of older adults is currently controversial , owing primarily to a lack of 
consensus on definitions of sarcopenia and obesity and limited data in non-Caucasian 
populations. As such, this review has identified several research gaps that should be 
investigated in order to improve our understanding of the risk factors contributing to 
sarcopenic obesity and musculoskeletal consequences associated with this condition. 
However, this thesis will only investigate some of the many identified literature gaps 
due to limited timeframe and capacity for initiating new trials as a result of the 
implementation of restrictions on research during Covid-19 pandemic. Understanding 
these relationships will aid in developing effective interventions to improve quality of 
life for older adults with and at risk of sarcopenic obesity.

 66 
Statement of aims 
Overall hypothesis and aim: 
Aim: This thesis examines risk factors for sarcopenic obesity and its effects on falls, 
fractures, and poor bone health in diverse populations of older adults. 
Hypothesis: Disadvantaged s ocioeconomic status is associated with higher 
prevalence of sarcopenic obesity among older adults . Individuals with sarcopenic 
obesity have an increased risk of falls, and fractures and poor aBMD and bone 
microarchitecture, compared to individuals without sarcopenia and obesity. 
 
Specific aims: 
Chapter 2 
Aim: To investigate if socioeconomic factors such as education, occupation and area 
of residence are associated with the prevalence of obesity, sarcopenia , and 
sarcopenic obesity in community -dwelling Australian older adults , and whether 
physical activity mediates these associations. 
Hypothesis: Socioeconomic inequalities increase the risk of developing obesity, 
sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity among older Australians, and insufficient physical 
activity at least partly explains the associations. 
 
Chapter 3 
Aim: To determine the incidence of, and compare risk factors for, incident fractures in 
older adults with and without obesity defined by BMI and body fat percentage. 
Hypothesis: Obesity defined by body fat percentage is associated with increased 
likelihood of fractures, whereas obesity defined by BMI is protective for incident 

 67 
fractures. Additionally, we hypothesise that sarcopenia components are associated 
with increased risk of fractures in individuals with obesity. 
 
Chapter 4 
Aim: To compare incidence of falls and fractures, and aBMD, in older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity to individuals with obesity, sarcopenia, and controls with neither 
condition. 
Hypothesis: Older adults with sarcopenic obesity have increased risk for falls and 
fractures, and poorer aBMD, compared to individuals with obesity and controls but 
have higher aBMD with lower risk for falls and fractures compared with individuals with 
sarcopenia. 
 
Chapter 5 
Aim: To investigate sex-specific differences in aBMD, BMAD and osteoporosis 
prevalence among Indian older adults with obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic 
obesity. 
Hypothesis: Indian older adults with obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity have 
lower aBMD and BMAD , and higher prevalence of osteoporosis, compared with 
counterparts with neither condition. 
 
Chapter 6 
Aim: To determine the relationship between BMI, body fat percentage and 
components of sarcopenia (muscle mass and muscle strength/power) with bone 
parameters assessed by HR-pQCT and DXA in older adults with obesity. 

 68 
Hypothesis: Higher BMI, but not higher body fat percentage, is associated with better 
bone microarchitecture . H igher muscle mass and muscle strength/power are 
associated with better overall bone health, including bone microarchitecture, in older 
adults with obesity.
