Chapter 2.0 – Associations between socioeconomic status and obesity, 
sarcopenia, and sarcopenic obesity in community-dwelling older adults: The 
Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort Study 
Chapter 2.1 – Introduction 
 Globally, the population is ageing at a rapid pace as is the prevalence of obesity 
(1). It is projected that 31% of Australian older adults will have obesity by 2025 (2). 
The confluence of ageing populations and obesity epidemics, may present many 
economic challenges to the Au stralian healthcare system as a result of increased 
hospitalisation and dependency (2, 10). 
There is limited evidence on risk factors that are associated with sarcopeni c 
obesity among older adults , particularly t he impact of socioeconomic determinants 
including education, occupation and area of residence . Limited data from primarily 
cross-sectional studies demonstrate conflicting associations between socioeconomic 
determinants and sarcopenic obesity (147, 160) . In addition, it is unclear whether 
sarcopenic obesity prevalence, like other conditions, has a socioeconomic gradient in 
older adults. With shifts in socioeconomic profiles in Australia, it is imperative to 
investigate whether socioeconomic status is an important factor contributing to 
obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity in older adults (147, 156, 157, 311) . It is 
unclear whether physical activity mediates the effects of socioeconomic status on 
obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity in older adults. 
If indeed socially disadvantaged individuals are more likely to develop 
sarcopenic obesity , and physical activity contributes to the associations between 
socioeconomic status and sarcopenic obesity , it will have major implications for 
primary prevention and management strategies in this population of older adults . 
Therefore, this chapter investigated if education, occupation and area of residenc are 

 70 
associated with obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity in community -dwelling 
Australian older adults and whether physical activity levels mediated these 
associations.

ABSTRACT 
Background: Social disadvantage may contribute to increased prevalence of sarcopenia and obesity. This study 
investigated if socioeconomic factors are associated with obesity, sarcopenia, or sarcopenic obesity (SO), in 
community-dwelling older adults. 
Methods: This was a cross-sectional analysis of data from the Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort study. Obesity was 
defined by body fat percentage (Men: /uni226525%; Women: /uni226535%) and sarcopenia was defined as the lowest 20% of 
sex-specific appendicular lean mass (ALM)/height (m
2
) and handgrip strength. Socioeconomic factors investi -
gated were education (tertiary degree, secondary or no secondary school), occupation (high skilled white-collar, 
low skilled white-collar, or blue-collar) and residential area (advantaged or disadvantaged area). Multinomial 
logistic regression analyses yielding odds ratios (95% confidence intervals) were performed and adjusted for 
potential confounders. Mediation analysis was performed. 
Results: 1099 older adults (63.0 /uni00B1 7.5 years; 51.1% women) participated. Older adults with a tertiary degree 
were significantly less likely to have obesity (0.68; 0.47, 0.98) and SO (0.48; 0.24, 0.94) compared with those 
who had no secondary schooling. No associations were found for occupation. Similarly, older adults living in 
advantaged areas were significantly less likely to have obesity (0.61; 0.39, 0.95). Steps per day mediated the 
association between residential area and body fat percentage by 51%. 
Conclusion: Lower educational attainment, but not occupation, was associated with increased likelihood for both 
obesity and SO in community-dwelling older adults. Low physical activity levels in disadvantaged areas sub -
stantially contributed to higher obesity prevalence in this population. Further research is necessary to confirm 
whether similar associations exist in populations with greater levels of social disadvantage and to design effective 
community-based interventions. 
1. Introduction 
Age-associated loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength, known as 
sarcopenia, is associated with functional decline ( Scott et al., 2016 ; 
Deschenes, 2004 ). Loss of lean mass along with increases in adiposity 
during ageing increases the risk of sarcopenic obesity ( Abete et al., 2019 ; 
Batsis and Villareal, 2018 ; Scott et al., 2014 ). Sarcopenic obesity is 
associated with an increased risk of adverse health outcomes, morbidity 
and frailty among older adults ( Abete et al., 2019 ; Batsis and Villareal, 
2018 ; Scott et al., 2014 ). There is no consensus definition of sarcopenic

for clinicians to identify older adults who may require interventions to 
prevent or treat sarcopenic obesity ( Prokopidis et al., 2020 ). 
Socioeconomic determinants including educational attainment, 
occupation types, income and area of residence are important predictors 
of musculoskeletal health outcomes particularly in lower income 
countries ( Moreira et al., 2016 ; Alexandre Tda et al., 2014 ; Brennan- 
Olsen et al., 2019 ). The negative health implications of disadvantaged 
socioeconomic status (SES) on musculoskeletal health may be sustained 
throughout life ( Jeng et al., 2018 ). Limited cross-sectional and longi -
tudinal studies have reported that income, occupation and educational 
attainment are associated with obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic 
obesity in several countries ( Alexandre Tda et al., 2014 ; Moreno-Franco 
et al., 2018 ; Kim et al., 2018 ). However, to date, no studies have 
explored the relationship of SES factors with both sarcopenia and 
obesity among Australian older adults. Therefore, to address this 
knowledge gap, we aimed to determine associations between a range of 
SES factors and sarcopenic obesity in a population of community- 
dwelling Australian older adults, and whether physical activity levels 
mediate these associations. 
2. Methods 
2.1. Study design and participants 
Baseline data from the Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort (TasOAC) 
study, a prospective, population-based observational study which was 
conducted from 2002 to 2004 including 1099 older adults (aged /uni003E50 
years) residing in Tasmania, Australia, were utilised for this analysis. 
This study was primarily established to identify factors associated with 
the development and progression of osteoarthritis. Participants were 
recruited from a computer-based random number system from the 
electoral rolls in southern Tasmania. Participants were excluded due to 
contraindication for magnetic resonance imaging and if they were 
institutionalised. This study was approved by the Southern Tasmanian 
Heath and Medical Human Research Ethics Committee (H0006488), and 
all study participants provided written informed consent. 
2.2. Sarcopenia and obesity 
Height (m) and weight (kg) were measured to the nearest 0.1 kg and 
0.1 cm; headgear, accessories, heavy items of clothing including shoes 
and socks removed. Height was measured using a stadiometer (Leicester 
height measure) and weight was measured using an electronic scale 
(Seca Delta Model 707, Bradford, Massachusetts, USA). Body mass index 
(BMI) (kg/m
2
) was subsequently calculated using weight (kg) divided by 
height squared (m
2
). Waist and hip circumference were measured to the 
nearest 0.1 cm using a measuring tape which was then utilised to 
calculate the waist/hip ratio. 
Whole-body dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans were 
performed to measure appendicular lean mass (ALM) and total body fat 
percentage using the Hologic DXA scanner (Hologic Corp., Waltham, 
Massachusetts, USA). 
Hand grip strength was measured using a pneumatic bulb dyna -
mometer (North Coast ™ bulb dynamometer; adult 0-30psi, model no. 
70, 154). Participants were required to use their maximum force by 
holding the dynamometer for 3 s in a seated position with their hip and 
elbow at a 90
/uni25E6
angle. Participants performed this assessment twice in 
each of their hands, with a 30 s rest between the two trials, and an 
average of the two trials was used for analyses. 
Sarcopenia was defined as the lowest 20% of the sex specific ALM/ 
height (m)
2 
( /uni003C8.78 kg/m
2 
for men /uni003C6.96 kg/m
2 
for women) and hand 
grip strength ( /uni003C11.88 psi for men and /uni003C8.63 psi for women). This is 
consistent with the methodologies used to obtain cut-points recom -
mended in the original European Working Group on Sarcopenia in Older 
People definition (EWGSOP1) ( Cruz-Jentoft et al., 2010 ). With the 
recommended cut-points from the revised European Working Group on 
Sarcopenia in Older People revised definition (EWGSOP2) we only had 3 
participants with low muscle mass and the dynamometer used in our 
study was pneumatic and therefore the EWGSOP2 cut-points for hand 
grip strength could not be applied ( Cruz-Jentoft et al., 2019 ). We also 
chose not to use the 2 standard deviations below the sex-specific mean 
definition for sarcopenia as only 10 participants had low hand grip 
strength and no participants had low ALM. 
Obesity was defined based on DXA-derived body fat percentage cut 
points of /uni2265 25% for men and /uni2265 35% for women as previously recom -
mended ( Romero-Corral et al., 2008 ; Okorodudu et al., 2010 ). Body fat 
percentaage was utilised for the main analyses as it is a direct and ac -
curate measure of adiposity which can avoid the misclassification of 
obesity status which may occur using the more common approach of 
BMI ( Gandham et al., 2020 ). Indeed, when obesity was defined by BMI 
/uni2265 30 kg/m
2 
in the present study, 333 (31%) participants had obesity and 
only 5 (0.5%) had sarcopenic obesity. Sarcopenic obesity was defined 
based on the classifications for sarcopenia and obesity mentioned above. 
For the purpose of this study participants were categorised into four 
groups as having one of the following: non-sarcopenic non-obesity 
(NSNO), obesity alone, sarcopenia alone or sarcopenic obesity. 
2.3. Education, occupation and area of residence 
Education, occupation and area of residence were all self-reported 
using questionnaires. Highest level of education was categorised into 
three subgroups: completed tertiary education, completed secondary/ 
high school or not completed secondary/high school. Similarly, the 
longest-held occupations were categorised into high skilled (HS) white- 
collar, low skilled (LS) white-collar, blue-collar or armed forces based on 
the International Standard Classification of Occupation (ISCO) coding 
system ( ILO, 1990 ; ILO, 2004 ; EuroFound, 2010 ). Area-level disadvan -
tage was matched with baseline residential address of each of the par -
ticipants in the study corresponding to the Australian Bureau of 
Statistics (ABS) Census Collection District for 2001. ABS software was 
then utilised to evaluate the Socio-Economic Indexes for Areas (SEIFA) 
score ( Brennan et al., 2013 ; ABS, 2001 ). For the purpose of this study, 
we employed the Index of Relative Socioeconomic Advantage and 
Disadvantage (IRSAD) in order to rank the relative advantage/disad -
vantage of the area in which people resided. Quartile cut points for 
IRSAD values were based on the study region of Southern Tasmania, 
Australia, as previously employed ( Brennan et al., 2013 ; ABS, 2001 ). 
2.4. Covariates 
Age, smoking status, protein intake and alcohol consumption were 
self-reported using questionnaires. Participants also reported if they had 
been diagnosed with any comorbidities (from a list including diabetes, 
heart attack, hypertension, thrombosis, asthma, bronchitis/emphysema, 
osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis 
and other major illnesses), from which a composite comorbidity score 
was calculated based on the number of positive responses. 
Physical activity was measured using pedometers (Omron HJ-003 
and HJ-102, Omron Healthcare, Kyoto, Japan) worn by participants 
on their hip for 7 consecutive days. Steps per day was calculated by 
taking an average number of steps across the days for participants who 
had data recorded for more than 4 days. 
2.5. Statistical analysis 
Characteristics of participants were reported as mean /uni00B1 standard 
deviation for continuous variables, or as percentages for categorical 
variables, according to sarcopenia and obesity groups. Chi-squared test 
was performed to evaluate the differences in proportion of older adults 
in each of the sarcopenia and obesity groups for each category of 
educational attainment, occupation types and IRSAD quartiles.

3. Results 
One thousand, one hundred participants were enrolled in the 
TasOAC study and baseline data was obtained for 1099 participants 
(mean age of 63.0 /uni00B1 7.5 years). Three participants had missing SES data, 
two participants had missing hand grip strength data and seven partic -
ipants in total had missing DXA data and were therefore excluded from 
the main analysis. Table 1 describes characteristics according to sarco -
penia and obesity status. Participants with sarcopenic obesity were 
older, less physically active and had higher BMI and waist circumference 
compared with the NSNO group. They also had a lower waist circum -
ference and BMI compared to those with obesity. A higher proportion of 
women were in the obesity and sarcopenic obesity groups compared to 
sarcopenia alone and NSNO. Participants with sarcopenia had lower 
BMI and waist circumference compared with both the NSNO and obesity 
groups. 
The proportion of older adults in sarcopenia and obesity groups in 
each category of educational attainment, occupation types and IRSAD 
quartiles are given in Fig. 1 . A higher proportion of older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity or obesity alone did not complete secondary 
schooling compared to the NSNO group ( p /uni003C 0.05). Similarly, a higher 
proportion of older adults with sarcopenic obesity had LS white-collar 
occupations compared with the NSNO group ( p /uni003C 0.05). In addition, a 
higher proportion of older adults with sarcopenic obesity or obesity also 
resided in the most disadvantaged areas (Quartile 1) compared with the 
NSNO group ( p /uni003C 0.05). 
The likelihood of having obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity 
was determined according to educational attainment, occupation types 
and area level advantage/disadvantage ( Table 2 ). In unadjusted ana -
lyses (Model 1), older adults who completed tertiary education were 
42% less likely to have sarcopenic obesity compared to those who did 
not complete secondary schooling. These results persisted after adjust -
ing for confounders including age, sex, total number of comorbidities, 
smoking status, protein intake and alcohol consumption (Model 2) and 
even after further adjustment for occupation types in (Model 3) ( P /uni003C
0.05). Older adults who completed tertiary education were 55 – 59% less 
likely to have obesity and 42% less likely to have sarcopenic obesity 
compared with those who completed secondary schooling in all three 
models. 
Older adults with HS white-collar occupations were 39 – 44% less 
likely to have sarcopenic obesity compared to those with LS white-collar 
occupations (Model 1 and 2). When obesity was set as the reference 
group, older adults with HS white-collar occupations were 49% less 
likely to have sarcopenic obesity compared to those with LS white-collar 
occupations after adjusting for confounders (Model 2). Participants 
residing in advantaged areas were 57 – 61% less likely to have obesity in 
both models (Model 1 and 2) and 43% less likely to have sarcopenic 
obesity compared to those residing in disadvantaged areas in the un -
adjusted model only (Model 1). 
Similarly, linear regression analysis demonstrated that older adults 
residing in advantaged areas had significantly lower body fat percentage 
(Model 1 and 2; Supplementary Table 1). Older adults residing in 
advantaged areas also had higher ALM/body fat percentage and hand 
grip strength/body fat percentage compared to those residing in disad -
vantaged areas (Model 1 and 2; Supplementary Table 1).

4. Discussion 
The primary finding of this cross-sectional study was that lower 
educational attainment and disadvantaged area of residence were 
associated with obesity and lower educational attainment was associ -
ated with sarcopenic obesity in community-dwelling older adults. 
Residing in disadvantaged areas was also associated with lower ALM 
and hand grip strength after adjustment for body fat percentage. 
Although an association was not observed between area of residence and 
sarcopenic obesity, steps per day mediated the association with obesity 
suggesting that public health interventions for prevention of obesity and 
sarcopenic obesity in older adults should include physical activity spe -
cifically designed for lower SES groups. 
Recent evidence indicates that educational disadvantages may have 
significant associations with sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity ( Jeng 
et al., 2018 ; Tyrovolas et al., 2016 ; Hwang et al., 2012 ). A study of 
10,325 adults from Louisiana, USA showed that lower educational level 
was associated with increased prevalence of sarcopenia and sarcopenic 
obesity among both men and women ( Jeng et al., 2018 ). Another study 
of 2221 Korean older adults aged 60 years and older also demonstrated 
that completing middle-school education or lower was associated with 
an increased likelihood of sarcopenic obesity among men ( Hwang et al., 
2012 ). Likewise, in the current study, older adults with lower educa -
tional attainment were more likely to have sarcopenic obesity and 
obesity compared to those with a higher level of education, but not 
sarcopenia. The lack of associations with sarcopenia may be due to low 
power given the small number of participants (particularly women) 
classified as having sarcopenia in this study. Higher education has been 
found to be protective against obesity as it increases cognitive abilities 
aiding in health-related knowledge promoting healthier lifestyles 
( Lawrence, 2017 ). Lower education may also lead to unhealthier life -
styles as a result of individual's having lower purchasing power due to 
their decreased capacity for income ( Santos et al., 2015 ; Aitsi-Selmi 
et al., 2013 ). 
Occupation type can also impact an individual's overall health ( Aitsi- 
Selmi et al., 2013 ). Income and occupation type are important social 
determinants that may contribute towards increased prevalence of 
obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity ( Kim et al., 2018 ; Dorosty 
et al., 2016 ). In a study of 644 older adults aged 60 years and over, those 
with low income had a higher risk of sarcopenia compared to those with 
middle or high income but in the current study the effects of income 
could not be directly evaluated ( Dorosty et al., 2016 ). However, in 
another study including 679 men aged /uni2265 65 years sarcopenia and sar -
copenic obesity were influenced by lifetime occupation, with individuals 
with white-collar occupations most likely to have sarcopenic obesity and 
obesity ( Kim et al., 2018 ). This is consistent with our results that in -
dividuals with white-collar occupations, particularly LS white-collar 
occupations, were most likely to have increased likelihood of sarco -
penic obesity compared with HS white-collar occupations. However, 
this association was attenuated after adjusting for educational attain -
ment, suggesting that this association is being driven by education. It 
was interesting that there were no differences between LS white-collar 
and blue-collar occupations which may suggest a protective effect of 
blue-collar work due to higher activity levels ( Kim et al., 2018 ). 
There is recent evidence that area of residence could also affect an 
individual's overall health ( Ghosh et al., 2016 ). In line with the current 
study findings, a study of 36,674 adults demonstrated a higher risk for 
obesity among both men and women residing in areas of high socio -
economic disadvantage after adjusting for age ( Ghosh et al., 2016 ). A 
possible explanation for this could be that older adults residing in 
advantaged areas have better access to health care services and social 
support compared to those living in disadvantaged areas ( Lindgren 
et al., 2016 ; Shahar et al., 2019 ). In support, in a study of 887 com -
munity dwelling older adults aged 60 years and over, those living in 
rural areas were more vulnerable to sarcopenia ( Chrisman et al., 2015 ). 
In the current study older adults residing in disadvantaged areas 
demonstrated a higher risk of sarcopenic obesity and obesity. A possible 
explanation could be that older adults residing in disadvantaged areas 
have lower health literacy, multimorbidity, poorer dietary habits and 
lower physical fitness levels as a result of their low income and/or ed -
ucation ( Chrisman et al., 2015 ). The effects on sarcopenia however 
could not be evaluated due to the low number of older adults with 
sarcopenia. Although, it was notable that in the analysis using contin -
uous variables, there were no associations of ALM and hand grip 
strength with area of residence except when these variables were 
adjusted for body fat percentage. 
Overall, the effects of socioeconomic status in this study were more 
evident for obesity than sarcopenic obesity. Mediation analysis

residing in disadvantaged areas were less likely to be physically active as 
opposed to older adults residing in advantaged areas ( Lindgren et al., 
2016 ). Individuals residing in disadvantaged areas are prone to inactive 
lifestyles and may therefore be more likely to experience adverse health 
outcomes ( Shahar et al., 2019 ; Chrisman et al., 2015 ). A study of 3567 
participants aged 30 – 65 years from China reported that both physical 
activity type and intensity were different based on socioeconomic status 
with those with highest socioeconomic status more likely to participate 
in exercise ( Chen et al., 2015 ). Similarly, a recent systematic review has 
demonstrated that physical activity domains differed based on the so -
cioeconomic status, with individuals of lower socioeconomic status less 
likely to participate in vigorous activities compared to those with higher 
socioeconomic status ( Craike et al., 2018 ). Interventions that address 
socioeconomic barriers to participation in physical activity and exercise 
are required to reduce the overall disease burden which affects this 
population ( Chen et al., 2015 ; Craike et al., 2018 ). A recent review has 
suggested that group-based interventions with those that focus on 
physical activity rather than obesity prevention may be effective for 
older adults with low socioeconomic status ( Craike et al., 2018 ). Higher 
levels of physical activity alone may however not be as effective in 
reducing the risk of sarcopenia as opposed to engaging in higher in -
tensities of physical activity along with the consumption of nutrient rich 
diets among those living in disadvantaged areas ( Beenackers et al., 
2012 ; Gao et al., 2015 ; Granic et al., 2019 ; Lee et al., 2016 ; Marcos- 
Pardo et al., 2020 ). Further longitudinal studies are therefore required to 
understand the most effective interventions for preventing sarcopenic 
obesity among older adults with diverse socioeconomic status. 
There are several limitations to this study. Firstly, this was a cross- 
sectional analysis. All study participants resided in Tasmania, 
Australia and were 98% Caucasian. As such, the results may not be 
generalised to other populations, particularly those with substantially 
different SES profiles. It should also be noted that the data were 
collected between 2002 and 2004 and it is likely that there are shifts in 
SES profile over time, and therefore may not be representative of the 
associations in this population at the present time. Also, residual con -
founding and other confounders which were not assessed in this study 
could affect the associations between SES and sarcopenia and obesity 
groups. Other lifestyle factors such as nutrition behaviours could also 
mediate the relationships between SES and obesity. The associations 
based on gender could also not be evaluated in this study due to insuf -
ficient power particularly for the sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity

In conclusion, lower socioeconomic status, specifically lower 
educational attainment and disadvantaged area of residence, were 
associated with higher likelihood of obesity and lower educational 
attainment was associated with higher likelihood for sarcopenic obesity 
in community-dwelling older adults. The association of area of residence 
with obesity, but not sarcopenic obesity, appears to be mediated by 
physical activity levels. Further research is required in order to deter -
mine if similar associations exist in diverse populations and to under -
stand the most effective interventions for preventing sarcopenic obesity 
among older adults with diverse socioeconomic status.

Chapter 3.0 – Incidence and predictors of fractures in older adults with and 
without obesity defined by body mass index versus body fat percentage 
Chapter 3.1 – Introduction 
 Chapter 2.2 focused on identifying potentially modifiable risk factors, 
specifically lower socioeconomic status and physical activity, that contribute to 
sarcopenic obesity in older adults. The remaining thesis chapters explore associations 
of sarcopenic obesity, and its components, with falls, fractures and other aspects of 
bone and muscle health. If sarcopenic obesity is demonstrated to be an important 
contributor to these outcomes, interventions may be developed to target 
improvements in socioeconomic factors and physical activity levels in order to reduce 
incidence of sarcopenic obesity and associated falls and fractures in older populations. 
Several studies have investigated relationships between BMI and bone health (4, 312-
314). These studies have demonstrated that higher BMI is associated with higher 
aBMD in older adults, and that individuals with obesity defined by BMI have lower 
fracture risk compared with those with normal BMI (260, 312, 314). Risk of fractures 
at certain skeletal sites including the lower limbs however is higher among those with 
high BMI (257, 263). This increased site-specific fracture risk may be explained by 
several factors including increased falls risk. The dominant index used worldwide to 
define obesity is BMI, which is positively associated with aBMD but does not account 
for relative adiposity (8, 9) . Unlike BMI, DXA -determined body fat percent age is 
associated with poorer aBMD and potentially, increased risk of fractures (8, 9, 97, 
315). No studies have previously compared the associations between obesity and 
bone health defined by both BMI and body fat percentage in older adults. Therefore, 
this chapter compared and determined risk factors associated with incident fractures 
among older adults with obesity defined by both BMI and body fat percentage.

ABSTRACT 
Purpose: The aim of this study was to determine and compare risk factors associated with incident fractures in 
older adults with and without obesity, deﬁned by both body mass index (BMI) and body fat percentage. 
Methods: 1,099 older adults (mean ± standard deviation age = 63.0 ± 7.5) years, participated in this pro -
spective cohort study. Obesity status at baseline was deﬁned by BMI ( ≥30 kg/m2) obtained by anthropometry 
and body fat percentage (≥30% for men and ≥40% for women) assessed by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry 
(DXA). Total hip and lumbar spine areal bone mineral density (aBMD) were assessed by DXA up to ﬁve years. 
Incident fractures were self-reported up to 10 years. 
Results: Prevalence of obesity was 28% according to BMI and 43% according to body fat percentage. Obese older 
adults by BMI, but not body fat percentage, had signiﬁcantly higher aBMD at the total hip and spine compared 
with non-obese (both p-value < 0.05). Obese older adults by body fat percentage had signiﬁcantly higher 
likelihood of all incident fractures (OR: 1.71; CI:1.08, 2.71) and non-vertebral fractures (OR: 1.88; CI:1.16, 3.04) 
compared with non-obese after adjusting for confounders. Conversely, obese older adults by BMI had a sig -
niﬁcantly lower likelihood (OR: 0.54; CI:0.31, 0.94) of non-vertebral fractures although this was no longer 
signiﬁcant after adjustment for total hip aBMD (all p-value > 0.05). Mediation analysis conﬁrmed that aBMD 
meditated the e ﬀects of BMI, but not body fat percentage, on all incident fractures. Higher baseline falls risk 
score was the only consistent predictor of increased likelihood of incident fracture in obese individuals only, 
according to both BMI and body fat percentage (both p-value < 0.05). 
Conclusions: Obesity deﬁned by body fat percentage is associated with increased likelihood of incident fractures 
in community-dwelling older adults, whereas those who are obese according to BMI have reduced likelihood of 
incident fracture which appears to be explained by higher aBMD. Falls risk assessment may improve identiﬁ -
cation of obese older adults at increased risk of incident fractures. 
1. Introduction 
There has been a substantial increase in obesity and aging of the 
population in recent years [ 1,2]. Although older adults with obesity 
(deﬁned by body mass index; BMI) have high areal bone mineral den -
sity (aBMD) and generally demonstrate reduced risk of fracture com -
pared with non-obese counterparts, they are more susceptible to certain 
types of fractures [3]. Hence, low-trauma fractures are common among 
obese older adults and this could be explained by risk factors such as 
increased falls risk, higher numbers of comorbidities, poorer physical 
activity and nutrition [4–6]. 
Although obesity status is primarily deﬁned by BMI this may not be 
representative of an individuals' adiposity [ 7,8]. Dual-energy X-ray 
absorptiometry (DXA) is a low-cost and widely available technique for 
accurately measuring body fat, and aBMD, so may be useful in identi -
fying the eﬀects of adiposity on fracture risk in older adults [ 7,8]. We

non-obese men, suggesting that adiposity per se is not protective for

No studies have determined the risk factors and underlying me -
chanisms contributing to increased incident fractures among older men 
and women with obesity deﬁned by body fat percentage and BMI. It is 
important to identify predictors of fracture in obese individuals given a 
large proportion of fractures occur in this population [2], and these are 
associated with increased loss of independence, ﬁnancial burden, mor -
tality and morbidity rates [1,10]. The aim of this study was to compare 
incident fracture risk and associated risk factors among obese and non- 
obese older adults, deﬁned by both BMI and body fat percentage. 
2. Methods 
2.1. Study design and participants 
The Tasmanian Older Adult Cohort (TASOAC) study is a pro -
spective, population-based observational study of older adults aged 
between 50 and 79 years. Participants were randomly selected from a 
computer-based random number system from the electoral roll in 
southern Tasmania. 1100 participants were enrolled in the study; ap -
proximately 51.1% were women. Participants were required to attend 
Menzies Research Institute in Hobart, Tasmania, for the collection of 
data. 1099 participants had baseline data collected, 875 at 2.7 years 
follow-up, 769 at 5 years follow-up and 566 participants for the ﬁnal 
10 years follow-up. The study was approved by the Southern Tasmanian 
Health and Medical Human Research Ethics Committee and all parti -
cipants provided written informed consent. 
2.2. Sociodemographic and general health 
At baseline, age, demographics, smoking status, alcohol consump -
tion, energy intake and disease history were self-reported using ques -
tionnaires. Participants also reported whether they had been diagnosed 
with any comorbidities (from a list including diabetes, heart attack, 
hypertension, thrombosis, asthma, bronchitis/emphysema, osteo -
porosis, hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis and 
other major illness) and a composite comorbidity score was calculated 
based on the sum of positive responses. 
2.3. Medications 
At the day of the clinic visit, participants were required to bring all 
prescription or over-the-counter medications that they were taking. All 
details regarding medication use and prescription patterns were col -
lected. Any bone-strengthening or osteoporosis treatment related 
medications that were likely to inﬂuence aBMD including bispho -
sphonates, corticosteroids, calcium, vitamin D, progesterone and es -
trogen were considered as bone active medications. 
2.4. Incident fractures 
Fractures were self-reported at approximately 2.7, 5 and 10 years 
from baseline. Participants responded to the following question: “List 
any fracture you may have had since your previous interview for this 
study. Please list these by the location of the fractures (e.g. left thumb, 
right wrist)” [11]. Incident fractures were then classiﬁed as all fractures 
and non-vertebral fractures (all incident fractures except for the ver -
tebrae). 
2.5. Anthropometrics and bone parameters 
Height (m) and weight (kg) were measured at baseline with head -
gear, heavy items of clothing including shoes and socks removed. 
Height was measured using a stadiometer (Leicester height measure) 
and weight was measured using an electronic scale (Seca Delta Model 
707, Bradford, Massachusetts, USA). Body mass index (BMI) was cal -
culated as weight (kg) divided by height (m 2). Waist and hip cir -
cumference were measured to the nearest 0.1 cm using a measuring 
tape. DXA scans were performed to measure appendicular lean mass 
(ALM), total body fat percentage, aBMD at the total hip and spine using 
Hologic DXA (Hologic Corp., Waltham, Massachusetts, USA). 
Obesity was deﬁned by both BMI and body fat percentage. Obesity 
status by BMI was deﬁned using World Health Organisation (WHO) 
classiﬁcations: underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2), normal weight (BMI 
18.5–24.9 kg/m 2), overweight (BMI 25.0–29.9 kg/m 2) and obese 
(BMI ≥ 30 kg/m 2) [12]. Obesity was also deﬁned based on DXA-de -
termined body fat percentage; we used cut-oﬀ points of ≥30% for men 
and women ≥40%, as previously recommended [ 13,14]. For compar-
ison, we additionally explored cut-o ﬀ points of ≥25% (men) 
and ≥35% (women) as these are commonly used to deﬁne obesity in 
the literature [15]. 
2.6. Falls risk score 
Falls risk scores were estimated from the physical proﬁle assessment 
(PPA) at baseline [16]. Standardised z-scores were calculated based on 
the performance in ﬁve physiological domains including vision (edge 
contrast sensitivity), sensation (proprioception), strength (knee exten -
sion), reaction time and balance (body sway) [16]. A falls risk score of 0 
or less indicates low risk, 0 to 1 indicates a mild risk, 1 to 2 indicates a 
moderate risk and a score of 2 or above indicates a high risk of falls. 
2.7. Physical function assessments 
Leg strength was measured at baseline in both legs using a dy -
namometer and recorded to the nearest kilogram (TTM Muscular Meter, 
Tokyo, Japan). Participants were required to stand on the back of the 
leg dynamometer with ﬂat feet while looking straight ahead, with their 
head and back leaning against the wall. Participants ﬂexed their knees 
until 115° angle was obtained and then were instructed to hold a bar 
that was connected to the dynamometer ﬂat on the thighs using both 
hands. While keeping a ﬁrm grip on the bar and looking straight ahead, 
they had to lift the bar upwards with maximum force using their legs 
until a maximal contraction was achieved. Participants performed this 
assessment twice, where the higher score was recorded [ 17]. 
Knee extension (quadriceps) muscle strength was measured in the 
dominant leg to the nearest kilogram. Participants were required to be 
seated in a chair with their hip and knees at a 90 ° angle. A strap was 
positioned 10 cm above the lateral malleolus which was connected to 
the back of the chair and the participants were required to push against 
the strap with their maximum power. 
Hand grip strength was performed using a pneumatic bulb dynam -
ometer (North Coast™ bulb dynamometer; adult 0–30 psi, model no. 70, 
154) and was measured to the nearest kilogram. Participants were re -
quired to hold the dynamometer with their elbow at a 90 ° angle in a 
seated position measured in both hands. Participants were required to 
use their maximum force possible for three seconds and were required 
to complete this assessment twice in each of the hands with a 30 s rest 
between the trials. Mean scores of the two trials were used for the 
analyses. 
2.8. Physical activity 
At baseline, physical activity was measured using pedometers 
(Omron HJ-003 and HJ-102, Omron Healthcare, Kyoto, Japan). 
Participants were asked to wear these devices on the hip for 7 days. 
Steps per day was calculated for participants who had data recorded for 
more than 4 days by taking an average of physical activity across the 
days.

2.9. Statistical analysis 
All data analyses were performed using SPSS Statistics 25 (IBM, NY, 
USA). Proportions of obese and non-obese older adults deﬁned by both 
BMI and body fat percentage who experienced incident fractures (all vs 
non-vertebral fractures) were compared using chi-squared tests. 
Baseline descriptive characteristics were compared between non-obese 
and obese older adults according to BMI and body fat percentage using 
independent samples t-tests for continuous variables and chi-squared 
tests for categorical variables. 
Binary logistic regression and negative binomial regression were 
performed to determine the likelihood and rate of incident fractures for 
obese older adults compared with non-obese, deﬁned by BMI and body 
fat percentage. These analyses were adjusted for: age and sex (Model 1), 
and additionally, total hip aBMD (Model 2) and additionally, smoking 
status, steps per day, number of comorbidities, bisphosphonates and 
bone active medications (Model 3). 
Multivariable linear regression was performed to compare di ﬀer-
ences in aBMD (total hip and lumbar spine), ALM, falls risk score, knee 
extension, leg strength and handgrip strength (all continuous variables) 
at baseline between obese and non-obese by BMI and body fat per -
centage. These analyses were adjusted for: age, steps per day, energy 
intake, smoking and total number of comorbidities at baseline. 
Mediation analysis was also performed to determine the mediation 
eﬀect of hip aBMD on the associations between BMI and body fat 
percentage with incident fractures. Path X corresponded to the eﬀect of 
BMI (a) and body fat percentage (b) on hip aBMD. Path Y corresponded 
to the eﬀect of hip aBMD on incident fractures. The total eﬀect captured 
the direct (Z) and indirect (Z') e ﬀect pathway of BMI or body fat per -
centage on incident fractures through the mediator hip aBMD. In this 
analysis, the percentage mediation was used to calculate the eﬀect size 
using the formula: PM = XY/(XY + Z') = XY/Z [ 18]. 
Binary logistic regression was performed to determine univariate 
associations of clinical risk factors with incident fractures in non-obese 
and obese older adults according to BMI and body fat percentage. 
Clinical risk factors that demonstrated signiﬁcant (p-value < 0.05) as -
sociations with incident fractures among any of the obese and non- 
obese groups were subsequently included in multivariable binary lo -
gistic regression analyses. 
For all analyses, p-value < 0.05 or 95% conﬁdence intervals not 
including the null point were considered statistically signiﬁcant. 
3. Results 
In total, 1099 participants with a mean age of 63.0 ± 7.5 years 
(51.1% women) were enrolled at baseline. Among these participants, 
7.1% reported at least one incident fracture and 3.7% reported more 
than one fracture. There were a total of 210 incident fractures over 
10 years, the majority (88.1%) of which were non-vertebral fractures. 
Table 1 presents comparison of baseline descriptive characteristics ac -
cording to obesity status deﬁned by BMI and body fat percentage. The 
prevalence of obesity based on BMI classiﬁcations was lower (27.6%) 
than the prevalence of obesity by body fat percentage (43.0%). Obese 
older adults by body fat percentage, but not by BMI, were more likely to 
be women and had lower physical function compared with non-obese 
(p-value < 0.05). Obese older adults by BMI, but not body fat percen -
tage, had higher aBMD at the total hip and lumbar spine compared with 
non-obese adults. Other di ﬀerences in descriptive characteristics be -
tween non-obese and obese older adults were similar regardless of how 
obesity was deﬁned. 
Proportion of incident fractures according to obesity status (non- 
obese vs obese) deﬁned by BMI and body fat percentage are presented 
in Fig. 1. Odds ratios and incidence rate ratios for all and non-vertebral 
incident fractures in obese compared with non-obese older adults de -
ﬁned by BMI and body fat percentage are presented in Table 2. Obese 
older adults by BMI had 40–50% lower likelihood and rate of non- 
vertebral fractures after adjusting for age and sex (Model 1), but after 
further adjustment for total hip aBMD (Model 2), these associations 
were no longer signiﬁcant. Obese older adults by body fat percentage 
(≥30% men; ≥40% women) had signiﬁcantly higher likelihood of all 
and non-vertebral fractures compared to non-obese after adjusting for 
confounders including age, sex, hip aBMD, smoking status, steps per 
day, number of comorbidities, bisphosphonates and any bone active 
medications at baseline (Model 3). However, as demonstrated in Sup -
plementary Table 1 there were no substantial di ﬀerences in the like -
lihood or rate of incident fractures between obese and non-obese par -
ticipants in the multivariable model when obesity was deﬁned using 
lower body fat percentage cut-o ﬀs (≥20% men; ≥35% women). 
Multivariable linear regression analyses ( Table 3 ) revealed that 
obese older adults by BMI, but not by body fat percentage, had sig -
niﬁcantly higher lumbar spine aBMD and ALM, and lower falls risk 
score compared to non-obese. However, obese older adults by body fat 
percentage, but not by BMI, had signiﬁcantly lower knee extension, leg 
strength and hand grip strength compared to non-obese. 
Mediation analysis (Fig. 2) demonstrated the relationship between 
BMI, body fat percentage and incident fractures with hip aBMD as the 
mediator. The percentage mediation ( PM) e ﬀect of 50.1% for BMI 
suggested that total hip aBMD was a strong mediator for all fractures (p- 
value < 0.05). However, this was not observed for non-vertebral frac -
tures and total hip aBMD did not mediate the e ﬀect of body fat per -
centage on all incident fractures. 
Table 4 presents univariable associations of baseline clinical risk 
factors with incident fractures. Among all obese and non-obese groups, 
lower total hip aBMD was predictive of incident fractures (p-value < 
0.05). Higher falls risk score was predictive of incident fractures for 
obese older adults by both BMI and by body fat percentage. Lower ALM 
was also predictive of fractures among non-obese older adults by both 
BMI and by body fat percentage. 
Multivariable binary logistic regression (Table 5) demonstrated that 
higher falls risk score remained predictive of incident fractures for both 
obese by BMI and by body fat percentage. Higher leg strength was 
predictive of higher likelihood of incident fractures among non-obese 
older adults by body fat percentage however, among non-obese by BMI 
lower handgrip strength was predictive of incident fractures. Lower 
total hip aBMD was predictive of higher likelihood of incident fractures 
among non-obese by body fat percentage. 
4. Discussion 
This prospective study of community-dwelling older adults de -
monstrated that obesity deﬁned by body fat percentage was associated 
with increased risk of incident fractures, whereas the protective e ﬀect 
of obesity deﬁned by BMI was primarily explained by higher aBMD. 
This study also showed that falls risk score was a consistent predictor of 
incident fracture among obese older adults. These ﬁndings suggest that 
obesity should be classiﬁed according to relative adiposity, and that 
assessments of falls risk may have utility in predicting fracture risk 
among obese community-dwelling older adults. 
Incident fractures were more common among overweight compared 
to underweight and normal weight older adults. Consistent with this, a 
study of 5995 US men reported that most non-vertebral fractures (68%) 
occurred in those who were overweight or obese, and this appears to 
reﬂect the fact that a greater proportion of the older adult population is 
overweight or obese, rather than a protective beneﬁt of lower body 
weight for fractures [ 19]. Indeed, when comparing incidence of frac -
tures between BMI groups in the present study, the likelihood of ex -
periencing an incident fracture was actually lower for obese older 
adults deﬁned by BMI, compared to non-obese. A study of 51,313 
women aged 50 years and older also demonstrated that women with 
high BMI were at a lower risk of major osteoporotic fractures even after 
adjusting for aBMD [6]. We observed that the protective e ﬀect of high 
BMI for incident fractures was no longer signiﬁcant after adjustment for

hip aBMD, suggesting that the lower fracture risk could be primarily 
explained by their higher aBMD [20]. We also observed that the e ﬀect 
of BMI on fracture was mediated by aBMD, which was similarly re -
ported in the previous study, but we did not see a similar eﬀect of aBMD 
on the relationship between body fat percentage and fracture [ 20]. 
The diﬀerential eﬀects of high BMI and high body fat percentage 
may be explained by the fact that high BMI is consistently associated 
with greater aBMD, lean mass and physical function [21]. Higher body 
fat percentage appears to provide no advantage, however, and in some 
cases poorer values for these outcomes. In a study of 907 Korean 
postmenopausal women with a mean age of 65 years, BMI was posi -
tively associated with aBMD and vertebral fractures whereas, body fat 
percentage was inversely associated with aBMD and was considered a 
risk factor for vertebral fractures [ 22]. Another study of 6776 meta -
bolically healthy adults demonstrated that high body fat percentage 
was negatively associated with aBMD and bone health [23]. High body 
fat mass was also negatively associated with physical function, which 
may increase the risk of falls and therefore fractures [24,25]. Thus, the 
purported fracture risk associated with obesity is likely to di ﬀer de -
pending on whether this is deﬁned by high BMI or high fat mass

strength would have conﬂicting associations with fracture risk, but 
individuals with higher lower-limb strength may be more likely to en -
gage in risky or high-di ﬃculty mobility-related tasks increasing their 
risk for falls, and thereby, fractures. A study of 1329 participants aged 
65 years and older demonstrated that physically ﬁt older adults had 
increased risk of falling when participating in certain types of sports 
demanding high-intensity activity patterns [ 29]. It should be noted 
however that while these associations were signiﬁcant in non-obese 
participants, their magnitude appeared to be small and did not diﬀer in 
direction from that of obese participants. Lower total hip aBMD was 
predictive of higher likelihood of incident fractures only among non- 
obese older adults by body fat percentage suggesting that aBMD may be 
a stronger predictor of fractures among non-obese older adults [ 30]. 
However, further longitudinal studies are required to conﬁrm these 
ﬁndings and to investigate the underlying mechanisms contributing to 
diﬀerences in fracture risk attributable to obesity status. 
This study is subject to limitations including the relatively low 
number of fractures. The study was not designed to explore predictors 
of incident fractures among obese older adults and due to the low 
number of fractures observed, it is possible that a lack of statistical 
power inﬂuenced our results. There was substantial loss to follow-up 
during the study period, and although we have previously reported that 
participants lost to follow-up in this cohort generally demonstrated 
poorer body composition, there were only minimal changes in the 
proportions of participants classiﬁed as obese at each time-point (data 
not shown) [31]. Nonetheless, it is important to note that obesity status 
was only determined at baseline, and it is possible that changes in body 
composition throughout the study inﬂuenced fracture outcomes [ 32]. 
Incident fractures were self-reported only every 2.5 to 5 years which 
may be subject to reporting error. Also, there is no consensus deﬁnition 
of obesity according to body fat percentage and the use of diﬀerent cut- 
oﬀs is likely to substantially inﬂuence associations and risk factors for 
fracture in those classiﬁed as obese; indeed, we observed that there was 
no association with fracture when lower cut-o ﬀs (that resulted in al -
most 80% of older adults being classiﬁed as obese) were utilised. It is 
likely that other clinical factors not measured in this study could have 
utility in fracture prediction in obese older adults, and that the risk 
factors included were assessed at one time-point only. 
In conclusion, obesity deﬁned by BMI and body fat percentage have 
conﬂicting associations with likelihood of incident fracture. Incident 
fractures were more common among obese older adults when deﬁned 
by body fat percentage compared to by BMI. Fracture prediction 
methods in obese older adults may be improved by using direct mea -
sures of relative adiposity, as well as physiological assessments of falls 
risk.

Chapter 4.0 – Falls, fractures, and areal bone mineral density in older adults 
with sarcopenic obesity: A systematic review and meta-analysis 
Chapter 4.1 – Introduction 
Falls and fractures are a major cause of disability and mortality among older 
adults (316, 317) . In Chapter 3.2 , older adults with obesity defined by body fat 
percentage had increased risk of incident fractures however the effects of comorbid 
sarcopenic obesity on adverse musculoskeletal health outco mes including falls, 
fractures and bone health are not well understood. Recent evidence has demonstrated 
that sarcopenic obesity is associated with increased risk of falls and fractures with up 
to three-fold increased risk among older adults compared with individuals with obesity 
alone and controls (without sarcopenia and obesity) (13, 274, 275). 
To date, no systematic review and meta-analysis has synthesised existing data 
to determine the risk for poor bone health, falls and fracture s in older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity. Therefore, this chapter compared aBMD, falls risk and fracture 
rates among older adults with sarcopenic obesity, obesity alone, sarcopenia alone and 
controls through a meta-analysis of existing observational studies.

Summary
Sarcopenia and obesity are common conditions in older adults that may have differ-
ing effects on falls and fracture risk. This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed
to determine whether older adults with sarcopenic obesity have increased risk of falls
and fractures or lower bone mass compared with older adults with sarcopenia, obe-
sity, or neither condition. Twenty-six studies (n = 37,124) were included in the sys-
tematic review and 17 (n = 31,540) were included in the meta-analysis. Older adults
with sarcopenic obesity had lower femoral neck areal bone mineral density (aBMD)
compared with those with obesity alone but had higher femoral neck aBMD com-
pared with counterparts with sarcopenia alone (bothP < 0.05). Older adults with
sarcopenic obesity had higher nonvertebral fracture rates (incidence rate ratio: 1.88;
95% confidence intervals: 1.09, 3.23; based on two studies), compared with those
with sarcopenia alone, and also had higher falls risk compared with controls (risk
ratio: 1.30; 95% confidence intervals: 1.10, 1.54) and obesity alone (risk ratio: 1.17;
95% confidence intervals: 1.01, 1.36). In conclusion, this systematic review and
meta-analysis has demonstrated that older adults with sarcopenic obesity are at
increased risk of adverse musculoskeletal outcomes compared with individuals with
obesity, sarcopenia, or neither condition. These data support the need for developing
interventions to improve bone health and physical function in this population.
KEYWORDS
falls, fracture, obesity, sarcopenia
1 | INTRODUCTION
One third of adults aged≥65 years fall at least once every year and
approximately 5% to 10% of these falls result in fractures that often
lead to disability, frailty, and hospitalization.1,2 Almost 40% of older
adults have obesity, and this is generally associated with normal or
higher areal bone mineral density (aBMD) and also results in increased
falls rates that may lead to an increased risk for fall-related injuries
and certain types of fractures.3 A number of factors including poor
balance and higher risk of obesity-associated comorbidities may
contribute to increased falls and fracture risk in older adults with
obesity.4–8
Prevalence of sarcopenia, the age-related decline in skeletal mus-
cle mass and function, varies based on the definition applied and can
range from 7% to over 50% in older adults. 9 According to the
European Working Group on Sarcopenia in Older People (EWGSOP)
criteria, prevalence of sarcopenia increases from 11% among older
adults aged 50–59 years, to 37% among those aged 80 years and
older.10 Recent findings indicate that sarcopenia is negatively associ-
ated with aBMD and increases hospitalization as a result of falls and

fractures.11,12 Older adults with the comorbid presence of sarcopenia
and obesity, known as sarcopenic obesity, have reduced physical per-
formance, increased risk of frailty and may be at a higher risk of
adverse musculoskeletal outcomes compared with those with sar-
copenia, obesity, or neither condition.10,13 It has previously been
reported that older adults with sarcopenic obesity have a threefold
increased risk for falls and fractures compared with counterparts with
nonsarcopenic obesity (obesity alone) and nonsarcopenic nonobesity
(controls).14 However, to date, no meta-analyses have investigated if
older adults with sarcopenic obesity represent a segment of the older
adult community who should be specifically targeted for falls and
fracture prevention programs.
We aimed to address this knowledge gap by performing a com-
prehensive systematic review and meta-analysis comparing bone
mass, falls risk, and fracture rates among older adults with sarcopenic
obesity, obesity alone, sarcopenic nonobesity (sarcopenia alone), and
controls.
2 | METHODS
2.1 | Search strategy
This systematic review was prospectively registered in the Interna-
tional Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO)
(CRD42019133773) and conducted in accordance with the Preferred
Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA)
guidelines.15 The electronic databases searched to November
21, 2020, inclusive were EMBASE (1947 to present), PubMed (Ovid
Medline 1946 to present), Web of Science, and Scopus. The search
included keywords “sarcopenia,”“ obesity,”“ falls,”“ fractures,”
“BMD,”“ older adults,” and related terms (Data S1). In addition, the
reference list in each of the articles included in the review were exam-
ined to identify any additional related articles that met the inclusion
criteria.
2.2 | Study screening and selection
Two independent reviewers (JM, AG) screened titles and abstracts of
all articles against the inclusion and exclusion criteria after the com-
pletion of the search strategy. All potentially eligible articles had full
text screened against the inclusion and exclusion criteria and then
data were extracted from eligible studies. A third reviewer was con-
sulted to resolve any disagreements (PJ).
We included randomized, quasi-randomized and observational
studies published in English which included adults aged≥50 years old
and provided: a measure of bone mass or falls or fractures among
older adults with sarcopenic obesity compared with those with obe-
sity alone, sarcopenia alone, or controls (or all three groups combined);
any objective measurement of obesity and any definition of sar-
copenia was accepted. Participants who were referred to as having
“dynapenia” (a term used to describe low muscle strength) were
considered to have sarcopenia given our definition included low mus-
cle mass, low muscle strength/physical performance, or both. Studies
were excluded if the participant population suffered from significant
comorbidities that are known to affect bone metabolism, for example,
cancer. Articles were also excluded if they did not contain primary
data (e.g., reviews, abstracts, data studies, letters, books, case reports,
meetings, and editorials).
2.3 | Data extraction
The following variables were extracted from articles independently by
two reviewers (JM, AG) using Covidence: author, year of publication,
number of participants, mean age, percentage of female participants,
study design, type of population, obesity, and sarcopenia definitions,
as well as falls, fractures, and aBMD outcomes. 16 When studies
reported data for both participants with sarcopenia and dynapenia
from the same population, only sarcopenia data were extracted. When
studies reported data for both participants with sarcopenic obesity
and “osteosarcopenic obesity” (the presence of osteopenia/osteopo-
rosis, sarcopenia and obesity) data for both groups were extracted
provided the two groups did not include the same individuals. We
contacted study authors three times over a period of 3 months due to
missing or insufficient data but those that did not provide additional
data were excluded from the meta-analysis.
2.4 | Quality assessment
The quality of individual studies was independently assessed by two
reviewers (JM, AG) using the Newcastle–Ottawa Scale (NOS) for
cohort studies and a modified version of the NOS for cross-sectional
study designs.17 Study quality was assessed based on the following
characteristics: participant age, selection of nonexposed participants,
assessment of falls, fractures and aBMD, definition of sarcopenia and
obesity, any adjustment for confounding variables, and missing
data (Data S2). The scale varied based on the study design. Cohort
study scores ranged from 0 to 10 based on above criteria and were
classified as high-quality if they scored ≥7 points. Cross-sectional
study scores ranged from 0 to 8 based on the above criteria and as
there were no cut-offs available, a median of≥4 points was consid-
ered as high quality.17
2.5 | Data analysis
Aggregated data were used, and an initial qualitative synthesis (sys-
tematic review) was performed. We also performed a quantitative
synthesis (meta-analysis) to explore the associations between
sarcopenic obesity, aBMD, falls, and fractures using Review Manager
(RevMan) v5.3.18 Studies were included in each of the analyses more
than once to enable comparisons between individuals with sarcopenic
obesity and each comparator (controls, sarcopenia alone, obesity

alone). Despite studies being included in forest plots more than once,
they were all independent of each other as we only presented subto-
tal mean differences between older adults with sarcopenic obesity
group and each comparator. Some studies compared only two groups
(older adults with sarcopenic obesity versus all others) rather than all
four potential categories of sarcopenic obesity. In these cases, the
comparator group would include not only controls but also those with
obesity alone and sarcopenia alone. Hence, we performed a sensitivity
analysis including only studies that compared all four groups for falls
outcome. Additional subanalyses were performed based on study
quality and sarcopenia definitions (studies that defined sarcopenia
using muscle mass assessment only versus studies that defined sar-
copenia using both muscle mass and strength assessments). Leave-
one-out sensitivity analysis was also performed for aBMD to evaluate
if the study with the highest weight in each of the femoral neck ana-
lyses was driving the significant associations.
We estimated raw mean differences for aBMD between groups.
Similarly, we estimated risk ratios and incidence rate ratios (95% con-
fidence intervals) for falls and fracture data, with individuals with
sarcopenic obesity group set as the reference. When studies reported
both crude and adjusted risk ratios or incident rate ratios, adjusted
data were used in the analyses. Meta-analyses were performed for
aBMD at the total hip, lumbar spine, femoral neck, and whole-body as
well as for falls risk and nonvertebral fractures using the random
effects model. Studies that did not provide data were not included in
the meta-analysis and those studies that did not have the data in the
required ratio format were converted into risk ratios or incident rate
ratios using the raw data provided in the studies via the calculator
function in RevMan. 18 Heterogeneity between the studies was
assessed using theI2 statistic where values≤25% were considered to
reflect low heterogeneity, 26% to 75% as moderate and >75% as high
heterogeneity.11,17 Publication bias was not assessed as there were
less than 10 studies included in each of the meta-analyses.19

3.4 | Sarcopenic obesity and aBMD
Figures 2–4 present mean differences in aBMD for individuals with
sarcopenic obesity compared with other groups (controls, obesity
alone, and sarcopenia alone) at the total hip, lumbar spine, and femoral
neck, respectively. Older adults with sarcopenic obesity had signifi-

sensitivity analysis (Figure S2) demonstrated that exclusion of the

62%) in this meta-analysis, resulted in a lack of significant mean
difference in femoral neck aBMD between individuals with sarcopenic
obesity and controls.
Older adults with sarcopenic obesity had significantly higher
aBMD at all three sites compared with counterparts with sarcopenia
alone (Figures 2–4). Older adults with sarcopenic obesity also had
significantly lower whole-body aBMD compared with individuals

alone (mean difference: 0.04; CI:0.01, 0.06) (data not shown). The

4 | DISCUSSION
This systematic review and meta-analysis demonstrated that older
adults with the combination of sarcopenia and obesity are at
increased risk of adverse musculoskeletal outcomes compared with
individuals with obesity alone, sarcopenia alone, and controls. Older
adults with sarcopenic obesity have lower aBMD at the femoral neck
compared with counterparts with obesity alone, and higher falls risk
compared with those with obesity alone and controls. Importantly,
despite having higher aBMD at the lumbar spine, total hip and femoral
neck, and a similar falls risk, compared with counterparts with sar-
copenia alone, our meta-analysis of two studies with incident fracture
data demonstrated their risk for nonvertebral fractures to be signifi-
cantly higher than that of those with sarcopenia alone.
To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to synthesize
data on differences in falls, fractures and aBMD between older adults
with and without sarcopenic obesity. A recent systematic review and
meta-analysis (n = 52,838) examined the associations between sar-
copenia, falls, and fractures.17 The authors reported that older adults
aged ≥65 years with sarcopenia are at a higher risk of falls and frac-
tures compared with nonsarcopenic counterparts.17 Further subgroup
analyses demonstrated that these associations were independent of
factors such as study design, population, sex, definition of sarcopenia,
continent, and study quality. 17 Another meta-analysis among
community-dwelling older adults ( n = 31,513) also focused on
associations between sarcopenia and fractures and reported an
increased risk of incident fracture in men with sarcopenia compared
with nonsarcopenic men when sarcopenia was defined by the Asian

Working Group for Sarcopenia (AWGS) definition.45 The increase
in fracture risk in individuals with sarcopenia may be partly explained
by increased falls as described above, but a meta-analysis in
adults aged ≥65 years has demonstrated that individuals with
sarcopenia have low femoral neck aBMD, which is also likely to
contribute.46
Conversely, in a meta-analysis of prospective cohort studies
(n = 3,126,313), Tang et al.47 demonstrated that obesity determined
by BMI was associated with a reduced risk of hip fractures. The pre-
sent meta-analysis conducted on only two studies suggests that this
protective effect of obesity on nonvertebral fractures is likely to be
lost in older adults who have comorbid sarcopenia, although larger
studies are required to determine whether this extends to hip frac-
ture. We observed that older adults with sarcopenic obesity have
lower aBMD compared with controls and those with obesity alone
but have higher aBMD compared with those with sarcopenia alone.
Low lean mass as a result of sarcopenia is associated with low aBMD,
which likely explains the poorer bone health of older adults with
sarcopenic obesity compared with both nonsarcopenic groups. 38
Higher body mass in individuals with obesity provides additional
mechanical loading on bone, which likely explains the higher aBMD
we observed in individuals with sarcopenic obesity compared with
counterparts with sarcopenia alone.48
We also observed that older adults with sarcopenic obesity are
more susceptible to falls compared with those with obesity alone and
controls but have similar falls risk and increased nonvertebral fracture
rates (88%) when compared with sarcopenia alone counterparts
(Figure 6).14 It was notable that fracture risk was also higher in individ-
uals with sarcopenic obesity compared with controls (32%) and those
with obesity alone (61%), although these differences were not signifi-
cant (Figure 6). These findings could be influence by only two studies
being included in the nonvertebral fracture analysis and their rela-
tively small sample sizes. Nonetheless, although both sarcopenia and
obesity have been associated with increased risk of falls,17,49 their
relationships with fractures are more controversial; obesity is gener-
ally considered to be protective but is associated with an increased
risk of certain fractures, including ankle and leg fractures.49,50
The absence of soft tissue padding in regions such as the ankle
and lower legs may make these sites more vulnerable among individ-
uals with obesity during a fall.50 However, BMI may not be truly rep-
resentative of an individuals' adiposity as it does not differentiate
between lean and fat mass. Recently, it has been demonstrated that

when obesity is defined directly by measures of adiposity using DXA,
there is no protective effect for fractures.51,52 Regardless, the evi-
dence from this meta-analysis confirms that older adults with
sarcopenic obesity represent a segment of the individuals with obesity
who are not protected from falls and fractures. Even in the presence
of obesity, older adults with sarcopenia should be considered for
interventions including resistance exercises to improve bone
health.53,54
It was somewhat surprising that despite falls risk being similar
among individuals with sarcopenic obesity and sarcopenia alone, and
aBMD being significantly higher in those with sarcopenic obesity,
there was a significantly higher risk for nonvertebral fractures for
those with sarcopenic obesity compared with those with sarcopenia
alone. The explanation for these controversial associations is unclear,
but it is likely that the advantage in aBMD observed in those with
sarcopenic obesity compared with those with sarcopenia alone is at
least partly related to their higher body weight, providing greater
mechanical loading of bone.55 Indeed, our meta-analyses demon-
strated that individuals with sarcopenic obesity generally had similar
aBMD to controls; the only exception was for femoral neck aBMD,
but a leave-one-out sensitivity analysis excluding the highest
weighted study confirmed similar femoral neck aBMD between
groups. This suggests that higher fat mass may counteract the delete-
rious effects of low muscle mass on aBMD through a mechanical load-
ing benefit, but further research is required to determine effects at
different skeletal sites. It is possible that the increased fracture risk for
individuals with sarcopenic obesity compared with sarcopenia alone
individuals is explained by compromised bone microarchitecture,
which has been demonstrated in individuals with high adiposity.56
Further studies using advanced bone imaging techniques are required
to better understand the effects of sarcopenic obesity on bone
parameters beyond aBMD.
This study has limitations. Only two studies were included in
the nonvertebral fracture analysis, and fractures were self-reported
and not radiographically confirmed in one of these studies, which
may be subject to reporting error and recall bias. It was only possi-
ble to explore associations with nonvertebral fractures and should
be acknowledged that associations of sarcopenic obesity with
incident fracture at specific sites may differ. However, a strength
of the falls and fracture analyses was that they included adjusted
incident rate and risk ratios that considered potential confounding
factors. The included studies highlighted the lack of a consensus
definition of sarcopenia or obesity, and it was necessary to include
studies with different diagnostic criteria. The definition applied for
both sarcopenia and obesity is likely to influence relationships with
musculoskeletal outcomes. Indeed, it was interesting to note that
sarcopenic obesity, when defined by both muscle mass and
strength, demonstrated more differences in aBMD with other
groups than when defined by muscle mass alone (Table S3). This
supports the use of multicomponent definitions including both mus-
cle mass and function in sarcopenia case finding. High heterogene-
ity observed for some of the analyses could possibly be explained
by different age distributions, sarcopenia and obesity definitions,
ethnicities, and analyses not controlled for sex. Attempts were
made to contact authors of studies with missing data, but some
data were not provided. Due to the low number of studies, sub-
group analyses based on age group, sex, and obesity definitions
were not performed. Subanalyses based on sarcopenia definitions
could not be performed for aBMD at the total hip, falls risk, or
nonvertebral fracture rates.

Although prevalence of sarcopenic obesity and understanding of
its associated burden on older adults is increasing, it is still not clini-
cally recognized. The lack of a consensus definition for sarcopenic
obesity makes it challenging for clinicians to diagnose or treat older
adults with this condition. Nonetheless, sarcopenic obesity is a poten-
tially modifiable risk factor for a number of health conditions that can
be reversed through lifestyle interventions.57 Weight loss has contro-
versial effects for older adults with obesity due to associated losses of
muscle and bone mass and increased fracture risk.4,58 Future studies
should focus on promoting healthy eating and targeted exercises such
as high intensity resistance and impact training, in order to maintain
and improve muscle and bone mass, while simultaneously undergoing
weight loss to reduce adiposity.59–61
5 | CONCLUSION
This systematic review and meta-analysis demonstrated that older
adults with sarcopenic obesity have increased risk of falls and have
lower aBMD at the femoral neck, compared with those with obesity
alone. Despite generally having higher aBMD, older adults with
sarcopenic obesity also have a higher risk of incident nonvertebral
fractures compared with counterparts with sarcopenia alone, based
on a meta-analysis of two studies. These findings support the need
to assess sarcopenic obesity status in the clinic and to improve
treatment guidelines for prevention of osteoporosis, falls, and
fractures.

Chapter 5.0 – Sex differences in bone health amongst Indian older adults with 
obesity, sarcopenia, and sarcopenic obesity 
Chapter 5.1 – Introduction 
Our systematic review and meta -analysis in Chapter 4.2 confirmed that older 
adults with sarcopenic obesity have an increased risk of falls and poorer aBMD 
compared with individuals with obesity alone and controls but also have an increased 
risk of incident non -vertebral fractures compared with individuals with sarcopenia 
alone. However, a majority of the studies in our systematic review and meta-analysis 
were limited to Caucasian populations and studies in diverse populations are currently 
lacking. It is possible that ethnic differences in body composition, metabolism, diet, 
physical activity, and genetics may contribute to differences in associations of 
sarcopenic obesity with musculoskeletal outcomes (318-320). 
Evidence from recent studies has indicated that there are sex differences in 
muscle loss as there is a greater decline in muscle mass in men compared to women 
in older age (321). These differences may be explained by several factors including 
sex-differences in hormones, physical activity, and distribution of body fat (107, 322, 
323). With increasing multimorbidity and ageing of the population in India, it is 
necessary to evaluate the effects of sarcopenic obesity on bone health to reduce the 
burden of this disease in this ethnic population of older adults . In this chapter we 
therefore aimed to determine sex -specific differences in aBMD and BMAD among 
Indian older adults with obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity.

Abstract
Age-related changes in fat and lean mass contribute to bone health, but these associations may be inﬂuenced by sex and 
ethnicity. This study investigated sex-speciﬁc associations of obesity and sarcopenia with bone mineral density (BMD) and 
bone mineral apparent density (BMAD) among Indian older adults. 1057 adults aged /uni2265 50/uni00A0years were included. Dual-energy 
X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) measured BMD at the hip, spine and whole-body, and BMAD was calculated as BMD//uni221Abone 
area. Obesity was deﬁned by body fat percentage (cut points; > 25% for men and > 35% for women), and sarcopenia was 
deﬁned using the revised Asian Working Group for Sarcopenia classiﬁcation with low hand grip strength (< 28/uni00A0kg for men 
and < 18/uni00A0kg for women) and appendicular lean mass index (< 7.0/uni00A0kg/m2 for men and < 5.4/uni00A0kg/m2 for women). Participants 
were classiﬁed into four groups: controls (no obesity or sarcopenia), obesity, sarcopenia, or sarcopenic obesity. Linear 
regression (/uni03B2-coeﬃ cients and 95%CI) analyses were performed with adjustments for age, smoking status, protein intake, 
and socioeconomic status. Prevalence of sarcopenia (37%) and sarcopenic obesity (6%) were higher in men than women 
(17% and 4%, respectively). Compared with controls, men with obesity had lower whole-body BMD and BMAD, but women 
with obesity had higher hip and spine BMD and BMAD (all p < 0.05). Men, but not women, with sarcopenic obesity, had 
lower hip and whole-body BMD and BMAD (all p < 0.05) than controls. Men with sarcopenia had lower BMD and BMAD 
at the hip only, whereas women had lower BMD at all three sites and had lower BMAD at the hip and spine (all p < 0.05), 
compared with controls. Obesity, sarcopenia, and sarcopenic obesity have sex-speciﬁc associations with BMD and BMAD 
in Indian older adults. With the aging population in India, it is important to understand how body composition contributes 
to poor bone health among older adults.

Introduction
The aging population of India is increasing at an exponential 
rate, and by 2050, 19% of the total population is predicted to 
be aged 60/uni00A0years and over, comprising 324 million individu-
als [1]. It is estimated that there will be parallel increases in 
chronic age-related diseases such as osteoporosis, and oste-
oporosis-related morbidity is likely to increase [ 2, 3]. Cur-
rently, osteoporosis aﬀects 1 in 5 adults aged 18–59/uni00A0years in 
India, with the prevalence higher in women compared with 
men [4, 5]. The onset of osteoporosis occurs approximately 
10–20/uni00A0years earlier in Indians compared with Western popu-
lations, highlighting their increased risk for low bone min -
eral density (BMD) [5]. It is possible that ethnic diﬀerences 
in body composition, dietary patterns, and physical function 
contribute to this increased prevalence among Indians com-
pared with Western populations [3, 4, 6].
