Chapter 7.0 – Discussion 
 The program of research detailed in this thesis has generated several novel 
and important findings on the aetiology and outcomes of sarcopenic obesity. The first 
chapter reviewed the literature and explored how risk factors including socioeconomic 
status, diet, physical activity, ethnicity, and sex may contribute to the prevalence of 
obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic obesity (92, 209) . The review highlighted that 
there is a paucity of research on how socioeconomic status is associated with 
sarcopenic obesity in older adults. This review also identified potential causes of 
adverse musculoskeletal health outcomes among older adults with sarcopenic 
obesity. Age -related alterations including changes in hormones, inflammation, and 
physical activity levels may contribute either directly or ind irectly to the development 
of increased adiposity and declines in muscl e and bone mass and quality. However, 
there is limited evidence on the relationship between sarcopenic obesity and 
musculoskeletal outcomes, and whether factors such as sex and ethnicit y influence 
these associations among older adults. 
Chapter 2 presents the first study to determine associations between 
socioeconomic status and sarcopenic obesity in a population of community -dwelling 
Australian older adults. This study also investigated if physical activity levels mediated 
the associations between socioeconomic determinants and components of sarcopenia 
and obesity. Lower educational attainment was associated with higher likelihood for 
obesity and sarcopenic obesity. Higher literacy levels promote healthier lifestyle 
choices and may also enable higher purchasing power as a result of increased 
capacity for earning higher incomes, which may support healthy eating (324, 325). 
Indeed, occupation and income are crucial determinant s of socioeconomic status , 
which contribute to the overall health of an individual (156, 326). In this study however 

 153 
there were no associations between occupation type and the risk of obesity, 
sarcopenia, or sarcopenic obesity. It is possible that the occupational classifications 
utilised in this study may be too broad to capture the wide range of socioeconomic 
disparities that may exist within these classifications , and the use of income levels 
may be more directly connected with obesity, sarcopenia, and sarcopenic obesity in 
older adults. In deed, disadvantaged area of residence was associated with higher 
likelihood for obesity in this study and this may more accurately reflect income 
compared with broad occupation categories. Individuals residing in advantaged areas 
have greater general literacy levels , which may allow them to make better health -
related decisions, and also have better access to facilities such as gyms and health 
care services, compared with individuals residing in disadvantaged areas (149, 327-
329). Mediation analysis demonstrated that physical activity was a strong mediator of 
the association between area of residence and obesity, implying that the benefit of 
living in advantaged areas can be attributed to higher levels of physical activity. Public 
health messages for the prevention of obesity and sarcopenic obesity should be aimed 
at changing physical activity behaviour particularly among individuals with 
disadvantaged socioeconomic status. There are several barriers to physical activity 
that individuals with disadvantaged socioeconomic status often face, some of wh ich 
include lack of motivation, time, and support (330, 331) . These barriers may be 
addressed by developing methods for implementing workplace physical activity or by 
encouraging group -based exercises. In addition, it is important to develop focus 
groups where these individuals have an opportunity to propose suitable activities 
which are both time efficient and can increase motivation for physical activity (332). 
These interventions may increase motivation , social interactions and encourage 
engagement in more moderate-to-vigorous activity, which may prevent and reduce 

 154 
obesity and sarcopen ia, and their effects on musculoskeletal health, among older 
adults with disadvantaged socioeconomic status (331). 
In Chapter 2, both socioeconomic status and physical activity increased the 
prevalence of obesity among older adults . With increasing prevalence of obesity , 
Chapter 3 therefore determined risk factors and underlying mechanisms contributing 
to incident fractures among older adults with obesity defined by both BMI and body fat 
percentage. The key finding from this study was evidence that the generally well-
accepted apparent protective effect of obesity for aBMD and fractures appears to be 
a direct result of the preferential use of BMI to define obesity. Although there is 
evidence that individuals with BMI-defined obesity are more prone to fractures at 
specific sites compared to individuals without obesity, elevated aBMD and increased 
soft tissue padding in obesity have contributed to a misconception that older adults 
with obesity are protected from fractures (263, 333-335). In this study, obesity defined 
by body fat percentage was associated with increased likelihood of incident fractures 
whereas, obesity defined by BMI was associated with reduced likelihood of incident 
fractures and this appeared to be explained by higher aBMD in those with higher BMI. 
Despite the fact that several risk factors were investigated in this study, including 
number of comorbidities, hand grip strength, leg strength and aBMD, falls risk score 
(standardised z -scores calculated based on performance in five physiological 
domains) was the only consistent predictor of incident fractures among those with 
obesity defined by both BMI and body fat percentage (298). This data suggest that 
assessments of falls risk score could be useful in identifying underlying risk factor for 
falls and predicting fractures in older adults with obesity, particularly given that aBMD 
is generally likely to be normal in this population . Although falls risk score is a valid 
predictor of incident falls, it may misclassify certain individuals as opposed to 

 155 
assessing incident falls as an outcome (336). In addition, specialised equipment’s are 
required to assess falls risk score which may not be readily available in all clinical 
settings (336). However, measuring incident falls generally requires large sample 
sizes with long follow-up periods in order to have sufficient statistical power. 
No systematic review and meta -analysis has previously investigated the 
associations of sarcop enic obesity with musculoskeletal outcomes including aBMD, 
falls risk and fracture rates . Since obesity defined by body fat percentage was found 
to have detrimental effects on fractures in the previous chapter (Chapter 3) and 
sarcopenia itself is associated with poor bone health, falls and fractures, it is important 
to investigate whether sarcopenic obesity confers increased risk of thes e outcomes 
compared with either condition alone , especially given the expected rise in the 
prevalence of sarcopenic obesity among older adults (337). Individuals with 
sarcopenic obesity had an increased risk of falls (expressed as falls incidence) and 
lower aBMD at the femoral neck compared to individuals with obesity alone and 
controls without sarcopenia or obesity. Although older adults with sarcopenic obesity 
had higher aBMD at the total hip, femoral neck, and lumbar spine, they also had a 
higher risk of incident non -vertebral fractures compared with individuals with 
sarcopenia based on a meta-analysis of only two studies. Both the studies included in 
this analysis defined obesity by body fat percentage and it is plausible that the 
classification of obesity in these two studies contributed to the higher observed risk of 
fractures. It is also possible that there are differences in bone microarchitecture, which 
could explain higher fracture risk despite greater aBMD among older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity compared with sarcopenia alone. The findings from this study have 
important impli cations for monitoring bone health and falls to prevent the risk of 
fractures among individuals with sarcopenic obesity. However, most of the studies in 

 156 
this systematic review and meta -analysis were limited to Caucasian populations and 
additional studies are required in diverse populations. 
Thus, in Chapter 5, we explored the sex-specific prevalence of sarcopenic 
obesity and its associations with bone density in a population of Indian older adults. 
Sarcopenic obesity was more prevalent in men than women, and there were sex -
specific associations with bone health. Men with sarcopenic obesity had worse aBMD, 
but both men and women with sarcopenia had lower aBMD, compared with controls 
without sarcopenia or obesity. However, women, but not men, with obesity exhibited 
better aBMD compared with controls. Differences in fat distribution, sex hormones, the 
age of onset of muscle degeneration , genetics , physical activity, and bone 
microarchitecture in this ethnic population of older adults may contribute to these sex-
specific relationships (322, 323, 338 -340). This study was however limited to two-
dimensional measures of bone health assessed by DXA, and the use of three-
dimensional imaging modalities such as HR-pQCT may capture effects of sarcopenia 
and obesity on bone structural parameters including cortical and trabecular bone 
microarchitecture which cannot be determined by DXA. 
Chapter 6 therefore involved an investigation of the associations of components 
of obesity (BMI and body fat p ercentage) and sarcopenia (muscle mass and muscle 
strength/power) with bone health assessed by both DXA and HR-pQCT in older adults 
with obesity. Obesity and sarcopenia components including BMI, ALM and stair climb 
power were associated with higher DXA -determined aBMD and bone 
microarchitecture assessed by HR -pQCT. Sensitivity analysis confirmed that h igher 
lean mass may contribute to the positive associations between BMI and bone health 
(341). There were no associations bet ween hand grip strength and bone 
microarchitecture, which could be explained by the fact that bone microarchitecture 

 157 
was only assessed at the tibia in this study. However, higher muscle power (assessed 
by stair climb power test ) was positively associated w ith cortical area and bone 
stiffness suggesting that muscle power may be a better indicator of bone 
microarchitecture in older adults with obesity compared with muscle strength. 
Conversely, body fat percentage was found to be adversely associated with cortical 
thickness, suggesting that higher body fat in older adults with obesity may have 
deleterious effects on bone microarchitecture, particular ly in the cortical 
compartments, and highlights that higher relative body fat is not associated 
with/beneficial for bone health in older adults. 
In summary, t his line of research demonstrates that socioeconomic status 
contributes to sarcopenic obesity in older adults and that musculoskeletal 
consequences associated with this condition include po or aBMD and a greater falls 
and fracture risk, which may be influenced by sex and ethnicity. More comprehensive 
musculoskeletal assessments for predicti ng falls and fractures in older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity are required in diverse populations . Body composition 
assessments by DXA, and bone microarchitecture assessments evaluated by HR-
pQCT, may be useful in older adults with obesity, as associations of body fat rather 
than BMI appear to best represent the true relationship of obesity with bone health, 
and bone microarchitecture measurements may be less likely than aBMD to be 
influenced positively by greater body size. 
 
 
 
 
 

 158 
Limitations 
 There are some limitations to the research presented within this thesis. All 
original research chapters (Chapter 2, 3, 5, 6) utilised cross -sectional data in this 
thesis, and in order to identify causative effects of socioeconomic status on sarcopenic 
obesity, and of sarcopenic obesity on musculoskeletal health outcomes, longitudinal 
studies with larger sample sizes are required. In Chapter 2, due to the low numbers, it 
was not possible to evaluate the sex-specific associations between socioeconomic 
status and sarcopenic obesity. Studies have shown that there are sex -specific 
associations between socioeconomic status and obesity and it is vital to understand if 
similar associations persist among those with sarcopenic obesity for the development 
of appropriate interventions relevant to both men and women (342, 343). This study 
also collected data between 2002 and 2004 and these associations may not be 
representative of the socioeconomic status and body composition profiles of current 
populations of Australian older adults. Sarcopenia was defined using the lowest 20 th 
percentile of the sex-specific ALM/height (m 2) and hand grip strength, and therefore 
may not be comparable with other studies using different definitions of sarcopenia. 
Similarly, in Chapter 2, 3 and 5, body fat percentage cut -points based on previous 
recommendations were utilised since there is no consensus definition of obesity by 
body fat percentage (344). Therefore, it is important to note that t he use of different 
cut-points might influence the associations with incident fractures. In the meta-analysis 
in Chapter 4, due to low number of studies, it was not possible to perform sub-analyses 
based on age, sex, ethnicity, definitions of obesity and sarcopenia , which could have 
explained the high heterogeneity observed for some of the analyses. Only two studies 
were included for the meta-analysis of associations of incident fractures. Additionally, 
Chapter 3 and 5 were both limited to DXA to assess bone health. The use of three-

 159 
dimensional imaging technology such as HR-pQCT to assess bone microarchitecture 
may provide better insights into the relationship between sarcopenic obesity and bone 
health in diverse populations. Additionally, since there is no consensus definition for 
sarcopenia, this study utilised the AWGS definition as it is the recommended 
diagnostic criteria in Asian populations, and the use of this definition may have 
influenced the observed associations with bone health. Furthermore, in this study all 
individuals resided in Hyderabad, India. Given diversity in lifestyle and environmental 
factors across geographical locations, these findings can not be generalised to other 
regions of India. Finally, Chapter 6 was a cross-sectional analysis from three studies, 
which consisted of a relatively small sample size. It is possible that lack of statistical 
power influenced our results. In addition, bone microarchitecture was only assessed 
at the tibial site in this study, and future studies should assess associations of 
sarcopenia and obesity components with bone microarchitecture at other skeletal 
sites. Considering fractures at the radius are the most co mmon types of fall -related 
fractures of the upper extremities in older adults with obesity, it is important to assess 
associations of components of sarcopenic obesity with bone microarchitecture at this 
skeletal site (345). 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 160 
Future directions 
 In light of the novel findings and limitations described above, this thesis has 
raised several new research questions which require further investigation. 
 This research program has demonstrated that higher BMI has a protective 
effect on bone health as obesity defined by BMI was associated with reduced 
likelihood of incident fractures (Chapter 3) and BMI was positively associated with 
aBMD and bone microarchitecture in older adults with obesity (Chapter 6). 
Conversely, body fat percentage was associated with increased likelihood of incident 
fractures (Chapter 3) and negatively associated with aBMD and bone 
microarchitecture particularly at the cortical compartments (Chapter 6) . Further 
research is required to corroborate these findings in various ethnic populations and to 
determine sex-specific and ethnic-specific cut-points to identify individuals with poor 
body composition who are at a greater risk of poor musculoskeletal outcomes. 
Among older adults with obesity, m uscle power was associated with more 
favourable bone microarchitecture (Chapter 6), suggesting this measurement , along 
with falls risk score (Chapter 3) may be useful in fracture risk assessments. This may 
be particularly true when only DXA estimates of aBMD, which are likely to be elevated 
in older adults with obesity , and not three -dimensional bone microarchitecture 
assessments, are available clinically to assess bon e health . In addition, t here are 
several pathophysiological and biological manifestations including lifestyle 
behaviours, hormones, and immunological factors that occur in sarcopenia and 
obesity which can adversely affect musculoskeletal health, and subsequently increase 
falls and fracture risk (79, 346). It is therefore important to evaluate if other risk factors 
not measured in Chapter 3 and Chapter 6 could have utility in predicting fractures and 
adverse musculoskeletal health in older adults with obesity and sarcopenia . Future 

 161 
research should investigate whether clinical factors such as physical activity , 
functional measures (e.g. timed up and go test), and bone microarchitecture can help 
identify important risk factors for fractures in this at -risk population of older adults 
(347). 
Sex-specific differences in prevalence of obesity, sarcopenia and sarcopenic 
obesity, and their associations with bone health, were observed in Indian older adults 
(Chapter 5). With the expected increase in the ageing of population in India, the 
prevalence of sarcopenic obesity is expected to increase. There is a paucity of 
research on how body composition contributes to poor bone health. Investigating this 
in larger cohorts will help determine risk factors associated with falls and fracture s 
among Indian older adults. Furthermore, development of various culturally -relevant 
interventions is necessary to reduce prevalence of sarcopenic obesity in diverse 
populations. Dietary patterns illustrat e lifestyle differences that exist across India 
because they are influenced by a variety of religious, cultural and family values, with 
certain populations forbidden to consume diets containing meat (348). As a result, the 
same intervention for improving muscle mass and function, and reducing fat mass, 
cannot be delivered to different demographic groups. Future studies should 
investigate the long -term effects of different diets and exercise modalities and 
intensities on musculoskeletal parameters during diet -induced weight loss in older 
adults with sarcopenic obesity from diverse populations. In addition, assessing body 
composition in these individuals is vital as lean mass and body fat are better predictors 
of health outcomes than BMI (349). However, in a low to middle income country like 
India, DXA may not be readily accessible. In such resource limiting setting s, health 
professionals may utilise bioimpedance analysis (BIA) as a surrogate measure of body 
composition as it is a relatively low-cost machine compared to DXA (350). In addition, 

 162 
results of the current study may be influenced by the inclusion of the lower age range 
as this study included individuals aged 50 years and over. Future studies should 
evaluate these associations in older age groups . Additionally, s ince there is no 
consensus definition for sarcopenia, in Chapter 5, the AWGS definition was utilised 
among an Indian community of older adults . However, this definition was largely 
defined based on data from Southeast Asian countries. Developing population-specific 
cut-points might produce alterna tive and therefore potentially more reflective result s. 
The use of the South Asian Working Action Group on SARCOpenia (SWAG-SARCO) 
consensus definition may accurately class individuals as having sarcopenia and 
sarcopenic obesity in South Asian populations, which may enhance the understanding 
of these conditions in ethnic populations (351). 
Several original research chapters in this thesis (Chapter 3, 4 and 5) were 
limited to two -dimensional measures of bone health assessed by DXA . Given the 
limitations of DXA highlighted above, additional studies using assessments of bone 
microarchitecture (e.g. HR-pQCT) are required. Similar methodological approaches in 
larger prospective cohort studies with three -dimensional musculoskeletal 
assessments are warranted. This will increase understanding of the impact of 
sarcopenic obesity on bone parameters other than aBMD. Although Chapter 6 
investigated the effects of components of obesity and sarcopenia on bone 
microarchitecture, it was limited to the assessment of bone microarchitecture at the 
tibial site and future studies should determine bone variables at the radial site as well 
as sites associated with major osteoporotic fracture burden including the hip and 
spine. 
 In Chapter 4, it was identified that older adults with sarcopenic obesity have 
poorer aBMD, and increased risk for falls compared with individuals with obesity alone 

 163 
and controls without obesity or sarcopenia but had a higher risk of fractures compared 
to individuals with sarcopenia alone. It is critical to develop interventions targeting 
reductions in fat mass with improvements in muscle mass and muscle 
strength/function to reduce the burden of this condition and its consequences for 
health care and disability -related services. Recent evidence has demonstrated that 
weight loss improves metabolic health among individuals with obesity, but also results 
in bone and muscle loss (312, 352, 353) . Studies on exercise intervention s in older 
adults have demonstrated that resistance programs such as high-intensity resistance 
and impact training (HiRIT) may be an effective strategy for preventing bone loss, but 
its effects on individuals with sarcopenic obesity undergoing weight loss are poorly 
understood (354-356). I am currently working on a pilot study at Monash University 
(Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registration Number: 
ACTRN12618001146280) that addresses this unmet need. Th is study is a 12 -week 
randomised controlled trial of older adults with sarcopenic obesity undergoing a dietary 
weight loss intervention and undertaking either supervised HiRIT or home -based 
aerobic exercise. If demonstrated to be feasible and effective for improving physical 
function in this pilot study, it will provide rationale for larger trials to determine whether 
HiRIT prevents muscle and bone mass losses during weight loss in older adults with 
sarcopenic obesity. The abovementioned pilot study also utilises three -dimensional 
measures of bone outcomes assessed by the HR -pQCT, which may provide further 
insights into the effects of an exercise and diet -induced weight loss intervention for 
improvements in musculoskeletal outcomes among older adults with sarcopenic 
obesity. In light of current lifestyles and overall convenience for older adults as a result 
of Covid-19 pandemic, it may be beneficial for future trials to also develop interventions 
in different settings, such as developing home -based high -intensity resistance and 

 164 
impact exercise along with caloric restriction supported by digital health tools such as 
smartphone apps. 
 Chapter 2 provided evidence that lower socioeconomic status is associated 
with sarcopenic obesity. Given data was collected between 2002 and 2004 in this 
study, with likely shifts in socioeconomic status profiles it is important to understand 
these effects in a contemporary population of older adults (357). A large prospective 
cohort study explori ng sex-specific associations between socioeconomic status, 
physical activity and sarcopenic obesity is therefore required. Given physical activity 
mediated the associations between socioeconomic status and obesity, future studies 
developing interventions for the preventi on of obesity and sarcopenic obesity among 
older adults should include physical activity programs specifically designed for 
disadvantaged socioeconomic status groups. Individuals who are socioeconomically 
challenged may need access to different modes of physical activity along with regular 
monitoring with focused support (331, 358). Physical activity should be promoted by 
educating individuals facing socioeconomic challenges about the advantages of 
participating in regular physical activity including improved social connections, social 
inclusion, active mobility, employability, and productivity (331). According to a recent 
review, these individuals should also be advised to participate in m ulti-component, 
intensive group -based exercise intervention s to have maximal benefits (331). 
Furthermore, this group of individuals may benefit from weight loss interventions in 
addition to physical activity as this may provide additional benefits in terms of 
increased physical function and independence (359). Further research should assess 
the long -term benefits of such interventions in older adults with disadvantaged 
socioeconomic status in diverse populations. 
 

 165 
Conclusion 
In summary, this body of work has highlighted risk factors contributing to 
sarcopenic obesity among older adults , and the musculoskeletal consequences 
associated with it. High BMI has a protective effect on aBMD, bone microarchitecture 
and incident fractures among older adults with obesity, but body fat percentage 
provides no such advantage and in fact has a detrimental impact on bone health. Body 
fat percentage may therefore be a more useful screening method for clinicians to 
identify individuals with obesity who are at increased risk of poor musculoskeletal 
health. In addition, a ssessments of muscle power and falls risk may help predict 
fractures among older adults with obesity. Individuals with the comorbid sarcopenic 
obesity are at increased risk of falls compared with obesity and controls and also have 
higher aBMD but increased fracture rates compared with individuals with sarcopenia. 
Comprehensive assessment of musculoskeletal health in this vulnerable group of 
older adults may therefore provide valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms 
contributing to this increased risk of adverse musculoskeletal outcomes as opposed 
to traditional measures of two-dimensional aBMD. Sex and ethnicity may also further 
influence the relationship between sarcopenic obesity and bone health . Sarcopenic 
obesity therefore warrants increased scientific, public, and clinical attention in diverse 
populations of older adults. The findings from this thesis may be of importance in 
directing future intervention studies developing population -specific prevention and 
management strategies to target prolonged independence in older adults with 
sarcopenic obes ity. Future studies should focus on characterising , and providing 
guidelines for the identification and management of, poor musculoskeletal outcomes 
in diverse populations of older adults with sarcopenic obesity. Implementation of these 

 166 
outcomes will support healthy ageing and improve the overall quality of lives of these 
individuals.

Abstract: Health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and physical function deteriorate with age and may 18 
adversely impact bone health in older adults. We determined associations of objective measures of 19 
physical function and HRQoL with bone health in postmenopausal women with low areal bone 20 
mineral density (aBMD). Fifty postmenopausal women (64.4  7.7 years old; mean  standard 21 
deviation) with low spine, hip or femo ral neck aBMD (T - or Z-score <-1.0) on dual -energy X-ray 22 
absorptiometry (DXA) participated. Femoral surface BMD, trabecular, integral and cortical 23 
volumetric BMD (vBMD) measurements were obtained using 3D-SHAPER software on DXA. Distal 24 
tibial vBMD and micr oarchitecture were assessed using high -resolution peripheral quantitative 25 
computed tomography (HRpQCT). Participants completed self-administered EuroQol-5D (EQ-5D) 26 
and modified falls efficacy scale (MFES) questionnaires , and physical function assessments. Stair 27 
climb power was positively associated with bone parameters at the hip, femoral neck and distal 28 
tibia (all p<0.05) in multivariable linear regression. EQ-5D demonstrated no significant associations 29 
with bone parameters and MFES was positively associated only with distal tibial cortical vBMD and 30 
cortical von Mises stress (both p<0.05). Objective measures of physical function, particularly muscle 31 
power, are more consistently associated with bone parameters compared with self-administered 32 
HRQoL questionnaires. 33 
Keywords: osteoporosis; postmenopausal women; physical function; bone; health -related quality 34 
of life 35 
1. Introduction 36 
Osteoporosis is an age -associated disease largely affecting postmenopausal women due to a 37 
steep decline in oestrogen levels following menopause [1,2]. Osteoporosis is defined as low bone 38 
mineral density (BMD) and bone microarchitecture increasing bone fragility and the risk of fracture 39 
[3,4]. The current clinical gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis is a du al-energy X-ray 40 
absorptiometry (DXA) scan which measures areal BMD (aBMD) [1,5]. Although DXA has many 41 
advantages, there are a number of limitations such as space restrictions in a clinical setting and 42 
equipment expenses. Hence, the development of cost-effective but reliable methods for identifying 43

individuals at increased risk for poor bone health are important in reducing the burden of 44 
osteoporosis. 45 
Age-related declines in physical function, particularly in postmenopausal women, are 46 
sequentially associated with loss of bone and bone mass [6]. Declining physical activity levels with 47 
age contribute to bone fragility and an increasing fracture risk in older adults [6, 7]. Individuals with 48 
better physical function are more capable of engaging in physical activity, which has a protective 49 
effect on bone health through mechanical loading [ 8]. Physical performance assessments can easily 50 
be incorporated into a clinical environment given they are generally feasible and have been 51 
recommended for risk assessment and diagnosis for a range of conditions including sarcopenia [8,9]. 52 
It is possible that they may also have utility for prediction of bone loss in older adults and may be 53 
useful for clinicians to identify individuals at risk of poor bone health [9,10]. 54 
Health-related quality of life ( HRQoL) comprises aspects of physical, emotional and mental -55 
wellbeing which are known to decrease with age [11]. HRQoL instruments are useful and inexpensive 56 
assessment tools for overall health status [ 11, 12]. While osteoporosis negatively effects HRQoL in 57 
older adults, it is also possible that declines in HRQoL contribute to reductions in bone health , in a 58 
bidirectional manner. Fear of falling may also be associated with HRQoL and increases with age 59 
resulting in lack of confidence in performing daily tasks, particularly in older women [12]. Both poor 60 
HRQoL and fear of falling may therefore be associated with bone health in older adults and could be 61 
clinically relevant self-reported measures to identify individuals at increased risk of osteoporosis [13]. 62 
The aim of the present study was to determine the associations between self-reported HRQoL, 63 
fear of falling, and objective measures of physical function with BMD and bone microarchitecture in 64 
postmenopausal women with low aBMD. 65 
2. Methods 66 
2.1. Study design and participants 67 
This analysis utilised baseline data from an exercise intervention conducted at the Monash 68 
Health Translation Precinct in Melbourne, Australia. Fifty community -dwelling postmenopausal 69 
women residing in Melbourne, Australia were recruited for this study. Recruitment of participants 70 
was achieved through advertisements in the local community, hospitals, businesses, and clubs . 71 
Inclusion criteria included: T- or Z-score at spine, hip or femoral neck -1.0; body mass index (BMI) 72 
< 30kg/m 2; <150 minutes of self -reported moderate to vigorous physical ac tivity per week ; and 73 
English-speaking. The study (ANZCTR number: ACTRN12618000101280) was approved by Monash 74 
Health Human Research Ethics Committee (HREC/16/MonH/364) and all participants provided 75 
written informed consent prior to completing any study assessments. 76 
2.2. Questionnaires 77 
At baseline, participants completed self -administered questionnaires including questions on 78 
demographics, medication use, disease history, smoking status and physical activity. HRQoL was 79 
measured using the EuroQol -5D (EQ -5D) [ 12]. The EQ-5D consists of five HRQoL dimensions; 80 
mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression. Participants selected one 81 
of three responses for each of the dimensions based on which an EQ-5D score was derived to measure 82 
the HRQoL status. Scores of the EQ -5D questionnaire range from 1 to 3, where 1 indicates no 83 
problems, 2 indicates some problems and 3 indicates extreme problems/ unable to perform that 84 
activity from which a total EQ-5D score (range: 5-15; higher scores indicate poorer HRQoL) has been 85 
derived. The modified falls efficacy scale (MFES) was used to assess fear of falls while completing 86 
certain tasks [14,15]. MFES consists of 14 questions related to a range of daily activities to determine 87 
confidence undertaking certain tasks (for example; get in/out of chair) [14]. Participants rated their 88 
level of confidence for each of the activities on a scale from 0 to 10, with 0 meaning not confident/not 89 
sure and 10 being completely confident/completely sure. Possible range of total scores in the MFES 90 
questionnaire were 0 to 140 (with higher scores indicating better confidence) [16]. 91

2.3. Physical Function 92 
Objective assessments of physical function were performed, including the stair climb power test 93 
(SCPT) and the short physical performance battery (SPPB). The SCPT was performed to evaluate leg 94 
muscle power and mobility performance [1 7]. Participants began the test from the base of a 10 -stair 95 
flight of stairs and were asked to climb the stairs as fast as possible, in a safe manner. The time taken 96 
for the participants to ascend the flight of stairs was recorded in seconds using a stopwatch. We then 97 
calculated stair climb power using the following formula: power = force X velocity [17]. Force was 98 
calculated as the product of participant body mass (kg) and acceleration due to gravity (9.8m/s 2). 99 
Velocity was calculated from the vertical height of stairs (1.75 metres) divided by stair climb time 100 
(seconds). The SPPB test consists of gait speed, chair stand and standing balance assessments and 101 
provides a composite SPPB score [18,19]. For the chair stand test, participants were required to stand 102 
up straight from a seated position five times as quickly as possible and the time taken was recorded. 103 
To complete the gait speed test, participants were required to walk 2.44 metres at a comfortable and 104 
normal pace. Gait speed was calculated by distance (walking course 2.44 metres) and time taken to 105 
complete the test (seconds). For the standing balance tests, the participants were required to hold two 106 
positions: semi-tandem and full-tandem, for 10 seconds. The semi-tandem stand involves placing the 107 
preferred foot in front of the other with the side of heel from the front foot touching the first toe of 108 
the other foot. The full-tandem stand is performed by placing the preferred foot in front of the other 109 
and the back of the heel on the front foot touching the toes of the back foot. A total score out of 12 110 
(higher scores indicate better physical function) was calculated based on the performance of the three 111 
tests: chair stand, gait speed and standing balance assessments [18]. 112 
2.4. Anthropometric, bone and blood biochemistry parameters 113 
Participants attended the clinic appointment following an overnight fast of  10 hours. A 20ml 114 
blood sample was collected by a qualified phlebotomist, and serum samples were analysed for 25 -115 
hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) using the DiaSorin Liaison (DiaSorin Inc, Stillwater, MN, USA) 116 
25(OH)D assay, a direct competitive chemiluminescent immunoassay. 117 
Height (m) and weight (kg) were measured with footwear, headwear and heavy items of 118 
clothing removed. Height was measured using a portable stadiometer (Seca 213, Germany), weight 119 
was measured using an electronic scale (Seca 804, Germany) and body mass index (BMI; kg/m2) was 120 
calculated. 121 
Each participant had a DXA scan (Hologic Discovery A, Hologic, USA), where aBMD and bone 122 
mineral content (BMC) were assessed at the total hip, femoral neck and lumbar spine using Hologic 123 
Apex software version 5.6.0.2. Osteoporosis was classified as T-score  -2.5 and osteopenia as T-score 124 
between -1 and -2.5, in line with guidelines from World Health Organisation [ 20]. Lumbar spine 125 
trabecular bone score (TBS) was assessed using TBS iNsight software version 3.0.2 (Medimaps, 126 
Switzerland). Using an algorithm, the 3D -SHAPER software (Galgo Medical, Barcelona, Spain) was 127 
applied to two-dimensional DXA scans of the proximal femur to model the femoral shape and BMD 128 
distribution in three dimensions , and then derived estimates for trabecular, cortical and integral 129 
volumetric BMD (vBMD) and surface BMD, a measure of fracture resistance [21]. 130 
High-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography (HRpQCT) scans (XtremeCT II, 131 
ScanCo, Switzerland) were performed to determine the integral bone quality and strength at the 132 
distal tibia [22, 23]. Briefly, the non -dominant leg was placed in a cast and stabilized to prevent 133 
movement and subsequent artefacts. A scout scan was used to place t he reference line at the tibial 134 
endplate. A subsequent scan of one hundred and sixty -eight parallel computed tomography slices , 135 
encompassing a 9.02mm region of the distal tibia was performed with an isotropic resolution of 136 
<55m. HRpQCT scans were then analysed using the manufacturer’s standard protocol, using 137 
software version 6.1. Trabecular and cortical bone parameters derived from HRpQCT included: 138 
trabecular cross-sectional area (mm2), trabecular thickness (mm) trabecular separation (mm; the mean 139 
space between the trabeculae), cortical cross-sectional area (mm), cortical vBMD, cortical porosity (%; 140 
the segmented pore volume ) and cortical periosteal perimeter (mm). [22,23]. Micro-finite element 141 
analysis was also performed to assess the effects of a simulated mechanical load to estimate trabecular 142

and cortical von Mises stress (MPa), which is used for fracture prediction with lower values 143 
indicating greater fracture resistance, as well as estimated bone failure load (N) and bone stiffness 144 
(N/mm2) [24,25]. 145 
2.5. Accelerometer-determined physical activity 146 
Each participant was provided with an Actigraph GT3X -BT accelerometer (Actigraph, 147 
Pensacola, CA, USA ) and instructed to wear the accelerometer at the side of the hip for seven 148 
consecutive days except during showering, water activities and sleeping. A diary was also provided, 149 
to record the time of the day that the device was worn and removed, time spent outdoors, physical 150 
activity performed and any issues that affected their physical activity estimates (for example, health 151 
issues resulting in low physical activity). The accelerometer data was recorded at a rate of 50Hz and 152 
transferred into ActiLife v6.13.3 software for analysis. Accelerometer activity was transformed into 153 
counts per minute (CPMs) with an activity threshold of 100 CPMs. The ActiLife software analysed 154 
data in epoch lengths of 60 seconds. Physical activity was categorised based on the following 155 
Freedson adult cut points of 1 to 99CPMs (sedetary), 100 to 1951 CPMs (light) and >1952 CPMs 156 
(moderate to vigorous physical activity, MVPA) [26]. MVPA was combined into a single variable due 157 
to the low amount of vigorous physical activity recorded in these postmenopausal women [27]. 158 
2.6. Statistical Analysis 159 
All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS software version 25 (IBM, Chicago, IL, USA). 160 
Data related to HRQoL and physical function were non -normally distributed, and so Spearman’s 161 
correlations were performed to determine associations for self -reported HRQoL (EQ-5D and MFES) 162 
and objective measures of physical function ( SCPT, SPPB and its components, with the exception of 163 
standing balance) with bone parameters. Multivariable linear re gression analysis was performed to 164 
further investigate these associations after adjusting for confounders including age, MVPA, BMI and 165 
25(OH)D. For all analyses, p-values <0.05 were considered statistically significant. 166 
3. Results 167 
In total, 50 postmenopau sal women were recruited with an age range of 49 -82 years (Table 1). 168 
Mean BMI was in the normal range with no current smokers in this population and the most common 169 
self-reported comorbidities were hypertension and hypercholesterolemia . The majority (88%) of 170 
participants had sufficient 25(OH)D levels ( 50nmol/L). Twenty -two (44%) participants had 171 
osteoporosis and twenty -seven (54%) had osteopenia, based on DXA T-scores. One 49-year-old 172 
participant had total hip and lumbar spine Z-scores of -1.5 and -0.9, respectively. No participants 173 
indicated extreme problems or an inability to perform activity in any of the five domains of the EQ-174 
5D questionnaire. Most participants (62%) had the maximum MFES score of 140, indicating general 175 
good health based on the self-reported HRQoL and fear or falling questionnaires. Participants spent 176 
almost three -quarters of their accelerometer wear time in sedentary behavior, and only 177 
approximately 5% of their time performing moderate to vigorous intensity activity. Twenty-nine 178 
(56%) participants had an SPPB score of 12/12 and participants had a range of 176-385W for the SCPT. 179

4. Discussion 239 
Our cross-sectional study in community-dwelling postmenopausal women with low aBMD 240 
demonstrates that an objective measure of muscle power is more consistently associated with bone 241 
parameters than other clinically-relevant objective measures of physical performance, self -reported 242 
HRQoL, and fea r of falling. This is the first study to compare associations of self -administered 243 
questionnaires and objectively measured physical function with bone health using advanced bone 244 
imaging. Our data suggest objective assessments, particularly the SCPT, may be used in screening 245 
individuals at risk of poor bone health in clinical settings. Given that physical assessments can be 246 
easily incorporated in clinical settings, they may serve as useful screening tools to help address 247 
current underdiagnosis of osteoporosis [28]. 248 
Total EQ-5D scores had no associations with any bone parameters . In contrast, a prior study of 249 
325 women with mean age of 60 years demonstrated that osteoporotic women have poorer HRQoL 250 
as estimated by EQ -5D questionnaires , compared with healthy individuals of a similar age [2 9]. 251 
Additionally, a study including 222 participants with mean age of 79 years reported that those with 252 
osteoporosis had poorer HRQoL even compared with those with osteopenia, although the HRQoL in 253 
this study was measur ed using the quality of life questionnaire of the International Osteoporosis 254 
Foundation (QUALEFFO-41), which specific ally measures osteoporosis-related HRQoL [30]. While 255 
we did not compare the women with osteopenia or osteoporosis in this study to a control group with 256 
normal aBMD, t he lack of association between HRQoL and bone parameters in this population is 257 
potentially explained by the overall good general health in the current study where the majority of 258 
women had either no or few problems for each of the EQ-5D domains. Nonetheless, longitudinal 259 
studies with a larger sample size are required to determine whether poorer HRQoL is predictive of 260 
an accelerated decline in bone health in older age. It is possible that an osteoporosis-specific HRQoL 261 
instrument may be more sensitive in detecting such a relationship. 262 
Despite the lack of association for total EQ-5D scores, the mobility and pain/discomfort domains 263 
of EQ-5D were associated with the bone parameters. A study of 1,000 Korean women aged ≥60 years 264 
reported that individuals with osteoporosis had significantly higher scores in the mobility, 265 
pain/discomfort and usual activities domains of EQ-5D [31]. The lack of association of usual activities 266 
HRQoL with bone health in the present study may relate to the fact that only a few women reported 267 
some difficulty with usual activities. It is possible that identification of women with reduced mobility 268 
and increased pain/discomfort could be a useful strategy to determine an increased osteoporosis risk. 269 
Our study is the first we are aware of to demonstrate an association between higher MFES scores 270 
(indicating lower fear of falling) and better cortical bone health, including distal tibial cortical vBMD 271 
and cortical von Mises stress. These associations were significant even after adjusting for 272 
confounders, including physical activity, in multivariable linear regression analyses suggesting that 273 
other factors associated with fear of falling , perhaps including mobility and pain/discomfort, may 274 
influence bone he alth in women with low aBMD. A study of 140 participants reported that fear of 275 
falling is increased in older adults with osteoporosis [32]. However, in the current study majority of 276 

J. Clin. Med. 2019, 8, x FOR PEER REVIEW 11 of 14 
 
the women with low aBMD had the maximum overall score of 140 , indicating t he lowest fear of 277 
falling. As demonstrated by the objective measures of physical function, and the fact that these 278 
women self -selected to participate in an exercise intervention, they likely represent a sample of 279 
postmenopausal population with a relatively low falls risk. Furthermore, a lthough knowledge of 280 
osteoporosis and awareness of a diagnosis increases fear of falls in older women [32], the majority of 281 
women in the current study were osteopenic rather than osteoporotic, and therefore less susceptible 282 
to fear of falling. Regardless, the association of fear of falling with cortical bone parameters warrants 283 
further investigation. 284 
Physical function is potentially an important predictor of fracture risk, largely due to its 285 
relationship with falls [33]. Previous studies have also suggested that improved physical performance 286 
is associated with better bone health. A study of 3,041 older adults reported that physical 287 
performance was moderately associated with hip BMD and we previously reported in over 3,300 288 
Swedish older adults that better performance in the timed up-and-go test was associated with better 289 
distal tibial trabecular vBMD assessed by standard peripheral quantitative computed tomography 290 
[34,35]. Surprisingly, chair stand time was not associated with any of the bone parameters in this 291 
study, and gait speed was significantly negatively associated with trabecular thickness and trabecular 292 
von Mises stress at the distal tibia. A study of 116 postmenopausal women observed that gait speed 293 
was positively associated with hip aBMD, but similarly found no associations between chair rise time 294 
and aBMD [36]. It is possible that gait speed has differing associations with bone compartments at 295 
different anatomical sites, given that the hip primarily comprises cortical rather than trabecular bone. 296 
A study of 1,061 Japanese postmenopausal women reported that gait s peed can be used in 297 
combination with lower extremity strength measurements as screening tools for low aBMD in 298 
postmenopausal women, but based on the findings of the present study, further research is required 299 
to explore its associations with bone microarchitectural parameters and vBMD [9]. Previous research 300 
has also demonstrated that physical performance tests can improve the predictive ability of existing 301 
fracture prediction tools, but the present study is the firs t we are aware of to indicate that a simpl e 302 
assessment of muscle power, rather than physical performance per se, is more consistently associated 303 
with bone health. Thus, future prospective st udies should explore whether the addition of muscle 304 
power assessment improves fracture prediction compared with other functional assessments [37]. 305 
Stimulation of bone formation through resistance exercise is necessary for the maintenance of 306 
bone health due to the insufficient mechanical loading obtained from daily activities in older adults 307 
[38]. Furthermore, high intensity resistance training has been shown to improve aBMD and enhance 308 
physical function in older women, and this exercise targeting muscle power may be superior to 309 
traditional resistance training for maximizing bone health in older age [39]. We observed that SCPT 310 
was positively associated with distal tibial trabecular area, as well as with femoral neck and total hip 311 
aBMD. Our findings therefore support the concept that improving muscle power may be beneficial 312 
for maintaining bone health in old er adults, although, as was observed for gait speed, SCPT was 313 
negatively associated with trabecular thickness at the distal tibia. It has been reported that increased 314 
mechanical loading through physical activity leads to changes to morphological parameters other 315 
than trabecular thickness [40], and trabecular number appears more important than trabecular 316 
thickness for maintaining bone strength [41, 42]. Hence, a negative association may not be a clinically 317 
significant finding and it should also be noted that trabecular thickness is a derived measurement 318 
from HRpQCT rather than a directly measured bone parameter [23]. As a result, assessments of 319 
muscle power in clinical practice a ppears potentially useful for screening for poor bone health in 320 
postmenopausal women. 321 
The results of this study are subject to limitations including its cross -sectional design, which 322 
limits conclusions on causality of any observed associations. It is likely that poorer bone health 323 
contributes to functional decline, poor HRQoL and fear of falling in postmenopausal women, but we 324 
did not ascertain whether previous falls and fractures influenced these relationships. The study had 325 
a relatively small sample size and it is unclear whether these results can be generalized to either men 326 
or populations with normal aBMD. Hence, longitudinal studies should be conducted in larger 327 
populations to confirm if objective measures of physical function are stronger and better predictors 328 

J. Clin. Med. 2019, 8, x FOR PEER REVIEW 12 of 14 
 
of decline in bone health compared with self-reported HRQoL and fear of falls questionnaires. The 329 
strengths of the study include a well-defined sample of women with poor bone health, the use of both 330 
objective and self-reported measures of physical function, and advanced imaging of bone including 331 
HRpQCT. 332 
In conclusion, a clinical assessment of muscle power was more consistently associated with 333 
microarchitectural bone parameters compared with other measures of physical function, and self -334 
administered HRQoL and fear of falling questionnaires, in postmenopausal women with low aBMD. 335 
In the absence of access to bone imaging devices such as DXA and HRpQCT, and given their 336 
concurrent association with risk of falls, it may be beneficial for clinicians to incorporate measures of 337 
muscle power in order to screen for poor bone health in older adults. Furthermore, interventions 338 
targeting improvements in muscle power may be effective in improving bone health in 339 
postmenopausal women at risk of osteoporosis. 340

Abstract
Purpose: This study was aimed to determine associations of accelerometer-determined time and bouts of sedentary behavior, light physical
activity (LPA), and moderate-to-vigorous PA (MVPA) with sarcopenia and incident falls over 12 months.
Methods: A total of 3334 Swedish 70-year-olds were assessed for sarcopenia, as deﬁned by the revised deﬁnition of the European Working
Group on Sarcopenia in Older People. Assessments were based on low scores for appendicular lean mass (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry),
hand grip strength, and the Timed Up and Go test. For 7 days after baseline, total time and total number of bouts (/C2110 min of continuous activity
at a given intensity) of activity performed at sedentary, LPA, and MVPA intensities were assessed by accelerometer. Incident falls were
self-reported 6 months and 12 months after baseline.
Results: Only 1.8% of participants had probable or conﬁrmed sarcopenia. After multivariable adjustment for other levels of activity, only greater
MVPA time was associated with a decreased likelihood of having low appendicular lean mass, low hand grip strength, and slow Timed Up and
Go time as deﬁned by the European Working Group on Sarcopenia in Older People criteria (allp < 0.05), and only MVPA time was associated
with lower likelihood of probable or conﬁrmed sarcopenia (odds ratio = 0.80, 95% conﬁdence interval: 0.71/C00.91 h/week). Similar associations
were identiﬁed for total number of bouts, with no evidence of threshold effects for longer duration of bouts of MVPA. A total of 14% of partici-
pants reported/C211 fall, but neither total time nor bouts of activity was associated with incident falls (allp > 0.05).
Conclusion: Higher amounts of accelerometer-determined MVPA are consistently associated with a decreased likelihood of sarcopenia and its
components, regardless of the length of bouts or amounts of sedentary behavior.
Keywords: Accelerometer; Falls; Older adults; Physical activity; Sarcopenia
1. Introduction
Sarcopenia, a muscle disease arising from adverse muscle
changes accruing across the lifetime, recently received an
updated operational deﬁnition from the European Working
Group on Sarcopenia in Older People (EWGSOP). 1 The
revised EWGSOP deﬁnition (EWGSOP2) differs from the
original one (EWGSOP1) in terms of suggested measure-
ments, cut-off points, and case-ﬁnding algorithms. In EWG-
SOP2, physical performance assessments are used only to
assess the severity of sarcopenia. This is in contrast to EWG-
SOP1, where physical performance was a primary component
of sarcopenia, and to the deﬁnition given by the U.S. Founda-
tion for the National Institutes of Health, where physical per-
formance is considered an outcome of sarcopenia. 2 These

different approaches may partly explain controversial ﬁndings

older adults.3 Nonetheless, we recently reported that older
adults with sarcopenia, as deﬁned by the EWGSOP2, are more
than twice as likely to experience falls over 12 months com-
pared with those without sarcopenia.4
Current World Health Organization physical activity (PA)
guidelines recommend that adults 65 years and older complete
150 min/week of moderate PA, 75 min/week of vigorous PA,
or an equivalent amount of combined moderate-to-vigorous
PA (MVPA), with aerobic activities performed in bouts (con-
tinuous activity performed above the MVPA threshold)5 of
/C2110 min.6 Accelerometers are a useful tool for objectively
estimating total duration and total bouts of sedentary behavior,
light PA (LPA), and MVPA. We previously reported that total
amount and intensity of accelerometer-determined PA is posi-
tively associated with lean mass and muscle strength in older
adults, whereas sedentary behavior demonstrates inconsistent
associations.7 Despite concerns that greater amounts of MVPA
may expose older adults to an increased risk of falls, older
women with low accelerometer-determined MVPA demon-
strate increased falls rates.8 It is unclear whether the length
of bouts of different activity intensities inﬂuences their
associations with sarcopen ia and falls, so determining
whether a threshold effect exists is important for public
health messaging.
Exercise, particularly resistance training, is recommended
as the primary treatment strategy for sarcopenia,9 and func-
tional activities and balance training seem to be key for the
prevention of falls.10 While strength training is recommended
in current PA guidelines, they focus primarily on general PA
rather than targeted exercise.11 It is therefore important to
understand associations of general PA with sarcopenia and
falls. The aim of this study was to determine associations of
accelerometer-determined totalduration and number of bouts of
sedentary behavior, LPA, and MVPA with EWGSOP2-deﬁned
sarcopenia and its components, as well as their associations
with incidence of falls over 12 months.

sections.materials and methods:
2.1. Study design and participants
The Healthy Ageing Initiative is an ongoing observational
study of 70-year-old adults residing in the Umea
/C14
municipality
in northern Sweden. The primary objectives of the Healthy
Ageing Initiative are to investigate traditional and novel risk
factors for cardiovascular disease and injurious falls and frac-
tures in 70-year-old men and women. Only 2 eligibility criteria
apply: speciﬁcally, that the individual is residing in the Umea
/C14
municipal area and is 70 years of age at the time of testing.
Potentially eligible individuals were sent written information
about the study, with contact information drawn from popula-
tion registers. Individuals either accepted or declined to partic-
ipate during a follow-up phone call. The study participation
rate was 69.5%. The Healthy Ageing Initiative was approved
by the Umea
/C14
University Research Ethics Committee and com-
plied with the World Medical Association’s Declaration of
Helsinki. All participants provided written informed consent.
The current analysis included the ﬁrst 3334 participants with
complete data for demographics, components of sarcopenia,
and accelerometer-determined PA.
2.2. Baseline clinic appointment
Participants attended a hospital near Umea
/C14
University for a
baseline clinic appointment, where they completed assess-
ments (detailed elsewhere in this article) and also had fasting
blood tests from which plasma glucose was analyzed. Height
and weight were assessed by stadiometer (Holtain Limited,
Crymych, Dyfed, UK) and scales (Avery Berkel HL 120,
Smethwick, West Midlands, UK), respectively, and body mass
index (BMI; kg/m2) was calculated. Participants also com-
pleted a questionnaire that assessed demographics, lifestyle,
and medical history. A Lunar iDXA (GE Healthcare Lunar,
Madison, WI, USA) whole body scan was performed to assess
soft-tissue composition (total fat mass and appendicular lean
mass (ALM)). Hand grip strength (HGS) was assessed using
an isokinetic hand dynamometer (Jamar; Patterson Medical,
Warrenville, IL, USA). Research nurses instructed the partici-
pant to hold the hand dynamometer in their nondominant
hand, maintain a 90˚ angle at the elbow joint, and keep the
elbow in close proximity to the waist. The research nurses fur-
ther instructed the participant to, on command, start squeezing
the hand dynamometer as forcefully as possible. The best of 2
attempts was subsequently recorded. The Timed Up and Go
(TUG) test12 was performed once to assess physical perfor-
mance; participants were asked to rise unaided from an arm-
chair and walk forward 3 m, then to turn around and return to
a seated position in the chair. Research nurses provided
instructions and a demonstration of the task, and measured
TUG time using a stopwatch.
2.3. Accelerometer-determined PA
Participants wore a triaxial accelerometer (GT3X+; Acti-
graph, Pensacola, FL, USA) for 7 days after the clinic appoint-
ment as described previously.13 Participants were instructed to
wear the accelerometer on their nondominant hip and to
remove it only when showering, swimming, or in bed at night.
To obtain representative accelerometer measurements, partici-
pants were also instructed to be normally active in accordance
with their current lifestyle. Participants who did not provide
/C214 days (including /C2110 h/day) of valid measurements had
accelerometer data excluded (approximately 10% of partici-
pants were excluded due to nonvalid wear time).14 Accelerom-
eter data were collected at a frequency of 30 Hz, and data were
transformed into counts of movement with an activity thresh-
old of 100 counts per min (cpm). Collected data were down-
loaded using ActiLife software (Version 6.11.2; Actigraph,
Pensacola, FL, USA) in epoch lengths of 60 s, with subsequent
wear time validation performed. Periods of/C2160 min with 0
activity were marked as nonwear time. Sedentary behavior
was classiﬁed as 1/C099 cpm, LPA was classiﬁed as 100/C01951
cpm, and MVPA was classiﬁed as/C211952 cpm, as proposed by
Freedson et al.15 MVPA was calculated as the sum of moderate

and vigorous PA; these PA intensities were combined due to
low amounts of vigorous activity in this cohort.16 Total time
(h/week) was calculated for each activity threshold, as well as
the total number of bouts (instances of continuous activity
within the respective activity threshold for each of sedentary
behavior, LPA, and MVPA) performed for each of the follow-
ing durations: 10/C019 min, 20/C029 min, 30/C039 min, 40/C049
min, 50/C059 min, and/C2160 min.
2.4. Deﬁnition of sarcopenia
The EWGSOP2 categorizes probable sarcopenia as low
muscle strength only, conﬁrmed sarcopenia as low muscle
strength and low muscle mass, and severe sarcopenia as low
muscle strength, low muscle mass, and poor physical perfor-
mance.1 The authors recently acknowledged a reporting error
with the published cut-point for ALM normalized to height.17
Due to this confusion, absolute ALM was used as the measure
of low muscle mass in this study. Hence, low muscle strength
was deﬁned as an HGS of<27 kg (men) or<16 kg (women),
low muscle mass as an ALM of<20.0 kg (men) or<15.0 kg
(women), and low physical performance criteria as a TUG
time of/C2120 s.1 Due to the fact that there were low numbers of
probable and conﬁrmed sarcopenia, and no participants with
severe sarcopenia, in this cohort, participants were classiﬁed
as having either no sarcopenia or probable or conﬁrmed sarco-
penia for the purposes of the present analysis.
2.5. Incident falls over 12 months
At 6 months and 12 months after the baseline clinical appoint-
ment, participants were contacted by a research nurse by tele-
phone to determine incident falls since the appointment.18
Participants were asked whether they experienced any falls that
were low energy (i.e., falls from standing height), where they had
unexpectedly come to rest on the ground (rather than any lower
level) by himself or herself. Individuals who reported/C211f a l l s
over 12 months were classiﬁed as fallers, and individuals who
reported/C212f a l l sw e r ea d d i t i o n a l l yc l a s s i ﬁ e da sm u l t i p l ef a l l e r s .19
2.6. Statistical analyses
All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS (Ver-
sion 25.0; IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA). Data were initially
checked for normality, and nonparametric tests were used
where appropriate. Descriptive data were presented as mean§
SD or median (interquartile range) for continuous variables or
frequencies for categorical variables. Differences in participant
characteristics according to sarcopenia status (no sarcopenia
vs. probable or conﬁrmed sarcopenia) were determined using
independent samplest tests or Mann-WhitneyU tests (continu-
ous variables), andx2 tests (categorical variables).
Multivariable binary logistic regression models were
used to determine odds for sarcopenia and its components,
and 12-month incident falls, per 1-h increase in sedentary,
LPA, and MVPA. An initial model was adjusted for sex,
BMI, and smoking status, andas u b s e q u e n tm o d e lw a sf u r -
ther adjusted for other activity variables (e.g., sedentary
behavior was adjusted for LPA and MVPA). Additionally,
given that sedentary behavior, LPA, and MVPA may have
U-shaped associations with incident falls and multiple falls,
these outcomes were compared across quartiles of seden-
tary behavior, LPA, and MVPA using x2 tests and multi-
variable binary logistic regression analyses.
Independent samplest tests were used to compare means for
total number of bouts per week at each duration for sedentary
behavior, LPA, and MVPA between participants without sarco-
penia and those with probable or conﬁrmed sarcopenia. Multi-
variable binary logistic regression analyses were then
performed to determine likelihood of sarcopenia and falls for
each additional bout per week of sedentary behavior, LPA, and
MVPA lasting for durations of 10/C019 min, 20/C029 min, 30/C039
min, 40/C049 min, 50/C059 min, and /C2160 min. These analyses
were adjusted for sex, BMI, smoking status, and number of
bouts of the same duration for other activity variables (i.e., sed-
entary bouts lasting 10/C019 min were adjusted for LPA bouts
lasting 10/C019 min and MVPA bouts lasting 10/C019 min).
Finally, multivariable linear regression models explored the
associations of total time and number of bouts of sedentary behav-
ior, LPA, and MVPA with components of sarcopenia (continuous
variables). These analyses were adjusted for sex, BMI, and smok-
ing status, as well as for total accelerometer wear time (total time
analyses) or number of bouts of the same duration for other activ-
ity levels (bout analyses). For all analyses, collinearity diagnos-
tics, including variance inﬂation factors and tolerance values,
were used to check for multicollinearity. Values ofp < 0.05 were
considered statistically signiﬁcant.
3. Results
Of 3633 participants initially recruited for this study, 3334
(50.5% women) had complete anthropometric, accelerometer,
and physical function data.Table 1presents characteristics for
participants classiﬁed as nonsarcopenic (98.2%), compared
with probable (0.8%) or conﬁrmed sarcopenic (1.0%). No par-
ticipant met the criteria for severe sarcopenia. There were no
differences in the proportion of men and women for the sarco-
penic and nonsarcopenic groups, but sarcopenic participants
were signiﬁcantly more likely to be smokers. Sarcopenic par-
ticipants tended to have lower BMI, but higher total body fat

4. Discussion
This population-based study of Swedish community-
dwelling 70-year-olds demonstrated that higher total amounts
and bouts of accelerometer-determined MVPA are consistently
and independently associated with a reduced likelihood of
probable or conﬁrmed sarcopenia, but not 12-month incident
falls. There was generally no evidence of a threshold effect for
bouts of increasing duration in terms of their associations with
sarcopenia and its components.

Physical activity, sarcopenia, and falls 581

To the best of our knowledge, this study is the ﬁrst to report
associations of accelerometer-determined PA and sedentary
behavior with odds for sarcopenia according to the revised
EWGSOP2 deﬁnition. 1 The primary differences between
EWGSOP2 and the original EWGSOP1 deﬁnition include the
recommended cut-off points for low muscle mass and strength,
as well as the conceptual stages of sarcopenia (EWGSOP1:
pre-sarcopenia, sarcopenia, and severe sarcopenia; EWG-
SOP2: probable sarcopenia, conﬁrmed sarcopenia, and severe
sarcopenia).1,20 We combined probable and conﬁrmed sarco-
penic participants due to the very low numbers of 70-year-olds
with EWGSOP2 sarcopenia in this cohort, which may reﬂect
the generally more conservative cut-off points of EWGSOP2
compared with EWGSOP1, potentially resulting in low
observed prevalence and limiting opportunities for early inter-
vention in community-dwelling older adults.4 Associations of
accelerometer-determined PA with each conceptual stage of
sarcopenia may be different than that observed for combined
sarcopenia stages. Indeed, Aggio et al.21 reported no associa-
tion between accelerometer-determined MVPA and EWG-
SOP1 sarcopenia in older men, but reported a signiﬁcant
decrease in the risk of severe sarcopenia. Similarly, higher
MVPA was not associated with a lower likelihood of having
sarcopenia according to EWGSOP1 in the UK Hertfordshire
cohort study,22 but the Toledo Study of Healthy Aging demon-
strated a 48% reduction in likelihood of sarcopenia per 1 h/day
increase in objectively determined MVPA, according to U.S.
Foundation for the National Institutes of Health criteria (which
include more conservative cut-off points for muscle function
than EWGSOP1).23 Taken together with our own observation
of a consistent association between MVPA total time and bouts
with EWGSOP2 sarcopenia, it is possible that the beneﬁts of
MVPA for preventing sarcopenia are most apparent for sarco-
penia deﬁnitions that use more conservative cut-off points.
Previous research has also demonstrated that accelerome-
ter-determined MVPA is associated with individual compo-
nents of sarcopenia. In Tasmanian older adults, accelerometer-
determined PA performed at light and moderate intensity was
positively associated with ALM, whereas sedentary behavior
had inconsistent associations with ALM.7 This ﬁnding is in
agreement with the ﬁndings of the present study, where total
time and bouts of LPA and MVPA, but not sedentary behavior,
were consistently positively associated with ALM. A study of
123 community-dwelling older Australians observed an asso-
ciation of longer sitting time with greater absolute lean mass
(1.2 kg per 1 h of sitting time, 95% conﬁdence interval:
0.44/C01.96; p < 0.01), but with signiﬁcantly lower lean mass
percentage, suggesting that perhaps sedentary behavior is asso-
ciated more strongly with increases in total body mass rather
than muscle mass speciﬁcally.24
Foong et al.7 also observed that light, moderate, and vigor-
ous PA, but not sedentary behavior, were all positively associ-
ated with lower limb strength. In the present study, only
MVPA was positively associated with HGS, and this may
reﬂect differences in common activities undertaken at different
intensities; for example, MVPA may be more likely than LPA
to include exercise involving upper limb contractions, whereas

LPA may most commonly involve walking. In support of this
possibility, we observed that LPA (as well as MVPA) was
independently associated with better TUG time. TUG was the
only sarcopenia component for which sedentary behavior dem-
onstrated a signiﬁcant association; greater amounts of seden-
tary behavior were associated with poorer TUG time
independent of LPA and MVPA. The Toledo Study of Healthy
Aging reported that only MVPA was associated with gait
speed,23 but a separate study found that greater sedentary
behavior is associated with slower TUG time in a cohort of
British 60-year-olds to 64-year-olds.25
The U.S. Physical Activity Guidelines Advisory Committee
recently published an umbrella review concluding that regular
PA delays loss of physical function and mobility and reduces
risk of fall-related injuries.26 Our results support the concept
that greater amounts of MVPA, for which the coefﬁcients were
of substantially greater magnitude compared with LPA and sed-
entary behavior, are associated with better physical function
(handgrip strength, TUG, and probable or conﬁrmed sarcope-
nia). It is unclear, however, why no associations were observed
with 12-month incident falls in multivariable models. This ﬁnd-
ing may be related to the fact that injurious falls were not
assessed and/or the low overall incidence of falls observed.
Also, greater amounts of sedentary behavior, although likely to
deleteriously effect physical function and mobility, likely protect
against falls by reducing ambulation and therefore exposures
that may cause falls. The incidence of multiple falls was lowest
in the quartile with the greatest sedentary behavior (although
this difference was nonsigniﬁcant) and was signiﬁcantly higher
in the lowest quartile of MVPA in unadjusted, but not adjusted,
analyses. Similarly, in a study of women aged 63/C099 years,
those in the lowest accelerometer-determined MVPA quartile
had 18% increased falls rates compared with those in the highest
quartile,8 although sensitivity analyses demonstrated that the
association was only present in women with poorer physical
function or with a history of/C212f a l l s .I m p o r t a n t l y ,t h eﬁ n d i n g s
of the previous study and our own demonstrate that greater
amounts of MVPA do not increase risk for falls. Given the clear
beneﬁts of MVPA for functional and other health outcomes,
clinicians should have conﬁdence in recommending that older
patients participate in activities at higher intensities.
This study is the ﬁrst we are aware of to examine whether
thresholds exist for associations of PA bouts of increasing
duration with sarcopenia and its components, as well as inci-
dent falls. Current guidelines recommend accumulation of PA
in bouts of /C2110 min based on data for cardiometabolic risk
factors, but accumulation of more PA bouts lasting/C2110 min is
not beneﬁcial beyond total volume of activity for reducing
all-cause mortality in older men.27 We observed similar asso-
ciations for sarcopenia and its components in the present
study; signiﬁcant associations between levels of activity and
sarcopenia components were consistently observed for both
total time of activity as well as number of bouts, suggesting
that the pattern in which activity is accumulated does not inﬂu-
ence these associations. Furthermore, there did not seem to be
a threshold at which the strength of association between bouts
of increasing duration with sarcopenia outcomes was
diminished. The only exception was the association between
MVPA and HGS, where the magnitude of the coefﬁcient
decreased and became nonsigniﬁcant for bouts of>49 min. It
is possible that this ﬁnding is explained by the low numbers of
MVPA bouts recorded at longer durations, and so it is likely
that increasing beneﬁts are obtained for lean mass and physical
function with increasing duration bouts of activity of/C201 h.
The primary limitation of the present study is that the associ-
ations among PA, sedentary behavior, and sarcopenia and its
components are cross-sectional. Although higher PA is likely to
contribute to improved muscle function, it is equally likely that
better muscle function enables participation in greater volumes
and intensities of PA.28 Falls were assessed prospectively at 6
months and 12 months, but only low-energy falls that resulted in
coming to rest at ground level were recorded, rather than falls
resulting in coming to rest at any lower level (i.e., partial falls
not resulting in falling to the ground), as commonly deﬁned in
other studies.29 The accelerometer cut-points for activity intensi-
ties used have been validated previously,15 but derived associa-
tions with sarcopenia and falls may not be comparable with
studies using different accelerometer devices and cut-points.30
Finally, as discussed previously, there was a low number of par-
ticipants with sarcopenia as deﬁned by EWGSOP2 in this com-
munity-dwelling cohort, and it is likely that our results cannot
be generalized to other older adult populations.
5. Conclusion
The ﬁndings of this cohort study of Swedish older adults
suggest that clinicians should encourage older adults to partici-
pate in longer durations of weekly MVPA to reduce the risk for
developing sarcopenia, and that this type of activity can be per-
formed without exposing older adults to increased falls risks.
Further prospective studies are required to determine causality
in the relationship between MVPA and sarcopenia, and
whether beneﬁts of MVPA persist over the long term.

to increased prevalence of sarcopenia and obesity and requires advocacy of optimal nutrition
treatments to combat their deleterious outcomes. Sarcopenic obesity, characterized by age-induced
skeletal-muscle atrophy and increased adiposity, may accelerate functional decline and increase
the risk of disability and mortality. In this review, we explore the inﬂuence of dietary protein on
the gut microbiome and its impact on sarcopenia and obesity. Given the associations between red
meat proteins and altered gut microbiota, a combination of plant and animal-based proteins are
deemed favorable for gut microbiota eubiosis and muscle-protein synthesis. Additionally, high-protein
diets with elevated essential amino-acid concentrations, alongside increased dietary ﬁber intake,
may promote gut microbiota eubiosis, given the metabolic e↵ects derived from short-chain fatty-acid
and branched-chain fatty-acid production. In conclusion, a greater abundance of speciﬁc gut bacteria
associated with increased satiation, protein synthesis, and overall metabolic health may be driven by
protein and ﬁber consumption. This could counteract the development of sarcopenia and obesity
and, therefore, represent a novel approach for dietary recommendations based on the gut microbiota
proﬁle. However, more human trials utilizing advanced metabolomic techniques to investigate the
microbiome and its relationship with macronutrient intake, especially protein, are warranted.

1. Introduction
Older population numbers are expected to rise dramatically over the upcoming decades across
the globe. By 2050, the worldwide population of those aged over 65 years is projected to increase by
approximately 10%, reaching 2.1 billion [1]. It is estimated that metabolic syndrome is prevalent in
12–26% and 12–37% of the European and Asian population, respectively [2]. Metabolic syndrome is
outlined by skeletal-muscle-insulin resistance, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and abdominal obesity [3].
In aging populations, prolonged malnutrition is linked to metabolic syndrome-related diseases,
